a9tEj7VCXGpopznnCqegdQ.review_text: As always, the food and service were top notch last night for our anniversary dinner. The two stars are for cleanliness and management. We sat at the bar while we waited for our table and I couldn't help notice how dirty it was behind the bar. The fronts of the coolers looked disgusting, which are being touched by the bartenders with their bare hands as they're making the drinks. The mirror behind the bar looked like it hadn't been cleaned in six months, with dried splatters and fingerprints all over it. It makes me wonder how clean other areas of the bar and kitchen really are. There's no excuse for that in a place of this caliber. As far as the management, they did nothing to quiet down some unruly people at the table next to us. Loud, drunk, belligerent behavior by a large party of rude, thoughtless guests, ruining the ambiance for all of the other guests in the dining room, is uncalled for. Everyone knew it was going on, including all of the staff, and none of the management said a word to them about it. For the exceptionally high price of dining here, I would expect better.

7FU0F2OuxI_VmzVsZ_DBcQ.review_text: I had dinner on a Sunday night and my experience wasn't good.  I called before and was told a hoodie sweatshirt and jeans were fine but got the impression that the employees judged me for it.  Service wasn't good.  My server seemed to neglect me quite a bit.  When I had questions about the menu, he excused himself to help other customers.  I don't mind waiting but he often walked by without even acknowledging me.  Something about his demeanor gave me the impression of looking down on me.  On the plus side, the bus boy was really quick with picking up plates.  The food was fine but didn't seem worth the price.  The view was a little disappointing because the restaurant sits among boat docks.

_FTBtYe8sTjbSUkm22e_mg.review_text: This restaurant did not live up to the reputation or location.  The server was OK, but the food was poor.  I had fish, of course, and it was mushy and bland.  I can say I've been there, but won't go back.

x5wPZc6EwodnRZptPoPjWA.review_text: Stumbled upon this place through yelp reviews. Arrived and waited 45 minutes for 5. The hostess was really nice and friendly. Got seated, water was poured quick and bread and butter came quick. We finished the bread and butter and still no waiter to take our order. After about 15 minutes, after we finished our bread, then a waiter finally came to take our order, not impressed with that. We should have been acknowledge not long after receiving our water and bread.   We ordered the Lazy Mans Cioppino. Plenty of seafood, good flavor, but we have had better. The soup was light.  21 Oz. Bone-in Cowboy Steak. This was good and even though this place is known for seafood, this steak was good, no A1 needed. Just the Gratin potatoes and bacon-bourbon butter with every bite of steak was enough.   I guess this would be the best restaurant on the wharf so far, but overall it's average.

lH3m71g_Eqor0NdtGaMwoA.review_text: Scoma was delicious. I went there on a Sunday night with my dad and grandparents and we were seated within 10 minutes, pretty amazing if you ask me. Our table had a pretty decent view too!  We ordered the Crab Louie Salad, which came with a mountain of crab. And when I say a mountain, it was like the Mt. Everest of mountains. It was probably one of the best Crab Louie Salads I have ever had. We also ordered a mixed seafood saute, which was also incredible. It came with some rice and steamed veggies, and just delicious. The best part about Scoma's was how perfectly all the seafood was cooked - especially the scallops!  There was so much food that the 4 of us had some heavy to-go boxes and I had an amazing lunch and dinner the following day. I'm not easily impressed by seafood restaurants but Scoma's definitely gets my stamp of approval.  Major plus -- free valet :)

z_b-hPr0d-Qhsb4VoLa2uQ.review_text: I really like the location and food, but service was horrible - one of the servants cannot put the water straight in the glass, the location of the table was near the cashier, waiters station - all evening they were standing near a looking at us or worse - talking loud it was new year eve and we were feeling that everyone who works at the restaurant was rushing and wants us to leave ASAP... When I booked the restaurant, I mentioned that we will be celebrating birthday , nobody even ask or propose something...  Overall I would not go there unless you know someone from the inside...

YjFHjrPPcDTjsNdjfRH9BQ.review_text: We had reservations well in advance of coming to San Francisco,  but still had to wait 10 min to be seated. I had the seafood mixture.  Lobster tails, scallops,  shrimp,  with rice and swiss chard. The lobster tails were gritty and not completely cleaned. The scallops and shrimp were cooked well. My wife had a similar dish with the same problems.  It was our main honeymoon dinner, fancy and what not, but the restraunt kinda sucked. The tables were super close together,  it was loud, the service was ok, but not great. I would Not recommend this place. The prices are high, and the quality was not.

gBpzv_xVL81_BY8HfKAN-g.review_text: Love this place, great atmosphere and view. Definitely a great place to stop for lunch while in SF. Kind of pricey, but anything with seafood usually is. Clam chowder is obviously amazing, paired with sourdough bread, of course. Crabcakes are really good also.

a__k1tpAjtCnlsm1PE6heA.review_text: Minuses: outdated decor and some very high menu prices  Pluses: best clam chowder of my life... My life.

jURsdln9hCEauhMnWPoOBA.review_text: Scoma's has been around before I was born and I've dined at the restaurant several times over the past years.  Recently, I had dinner at the restaurant which offered:  +  Friendly and Attentive Service +  A Wide & Varied Menu +  Fresh, Well Prepared Local Seafood +  Wonderful Fisherman's Wharf Water Views +  Old School Atmosphere - Restaurant has been around since 1965 +  A good assortment of bread  Besides a variety of appetizers, I had the "Lazy Man's" Cioppino as my main dinner entree.  It was a hearty tomato-based fisherman's stew with an assortment of seafood.  I usually like a spicier tomato base but my stew was still perfectly prepared and tasty.  I will continue to dine at Scoma's and I'm still a fan..... 4 Stars!

Nb-fJ4KsTGfNK3ZfdQRN6g.review_text: Crab season!  I'm not a big fan of shelling my own crab, but the wood fires dungeness(sp?) was worth the effort. Shelled it all and mopped it up with the shallot sauce with the buttery bread!  I will dream about this stuff!.  A nice visit from the owner and a shout out from the bar as we left-- great place where the owners work the restaurant and really care about customers.

zpiyQRFRXoYxk-zT2dLdMw.review_text: Feeling a bit bad to give a well liked establishment a poor review. I just didnt get the experience everyone talks about. The restaurant is classic but dated and slightly stuffy. Maybe I didn't order the right food but it was subpar. If I am remembering correctly, it was a platter that our server recommended. I love seafood and was not impressed here.

_VmNgHSyAjCtDGWaX1YKZQ.review_text: Stopped in yesterday for a glass of wine and a crab cocktail.  We sat at the bar and watched in amazement how well Francis handled the extremely busy  bar.  He was calm and handled the orders as they were coming in never showing anxiety.  I asked him if it was a normal day and he said "no, it was the second busiest day he saw".  He was working the bar by himself and handled it very professional.  He even took a minute just to  talk, never breaking his stride.  My hat is off to him.    The Dungeness crab cocktail was huge.  Scoma's is my go place for great seafood when I am in San Francisco.

RsIbmSXWRXJLBBlgQsb7tg.review_text: My parents are really into this place.  They go all out and order fancy pastas and dishes and blah blah blahhhh. I only like one thing: The Steak Sandwich. It's not on the menu anymore, but they make it still.  This place is pretty dated, but that's part of its charm. They've also had the same waiters foreverrrrr. It can get crowded/touristy depending on when you go.   Highlights of all of my experiences: -taking a picture of myself next to the picture of Al Scoma and sending it to someone and making them mad because they didn't get to go. -actually texting people pictures of ourselves there and making them upset is something i've done pretty much every time... hmmm -witnessing the most awkward first date/birthday celebration ever -shocking Canadian tourists with my loud conversation -seeing a little girl in a wedding dress but I guess that's like a communion thing lol -pedestrian purposely walking into our car just to be a little jerk -having the valet bring the car over to us and getting in the car while tourists watched and waited and Billie Jean is BLASTING, then driving off as fast as possible

ef99zSAFzmEGYF0Uh58JbQ.review_text: I've lived in the Bay area most all of my life and never heard of Scoma's restaurant till someone mentioned that it is an Icon of Fishermans Wharf. So feeling out of contact with the world I mentioned to my family that we should go there. Being a Chef myself and knowing what the food cost is on a plate.   I have to say that this restaurant was rather expensive for the quantity and quality  of the food. The food did not receive a 'Wow' moment but the final Bill did! I regret not just grabbing something to eat from the food vendors off the walkway. It would've saved me $150! Next time we go to SF we will go to our usual and yummy Nona Rose's.  This place is very very pricey and pretentious.  I don't mind paying the price if the food 'Wowed' me but it didn't, we walked away very disappointed.

yO0QyTuu5z-8wzcwtopwKw.review_text: I have been going to Scoma's for about twenty years, and it has been very good every time. It's my go-to seafood/Italian place at Fisherman's Wharf. There are other similar places equally or even better than Scoma's (ie. Café Sport)  in the city, but for the fisherman's wharf experience, Scoma's  is hard to beat. I always get the clams and pasta or the Ciopino, and they're consistently excellent. My daughter and wife ordered the battered Cod fish with vegetables, and they liked it. They have Valet parking, which is a plus. The view is gorgeous, and you can see boats along the wharf. This place has been consistently good, and it's hard to beat along the Wharf.

1Th9Ly4ogmR6PzntFC3y6A.review_text: By far the best restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf, Scoma's is one of San Francisco's best kept secrets. Hidden away on the "working" side of the Wharf, Scoma's features fresh crab and fish direct from the boat.

PI31c_wcFj5JPNnuKl8vKQ.review_text: Maybe we hit an 'off' night, based on some of the other reviews, but neither the service, the food, or the atmosphere was worth the cost.  Group of 5 colleagues, ordered 5 different meals, and only 1 out of the group was complimnetary about their meal.  I ordered broiled cod which was served in a bath of yellow oil, with a side of overcooked pasta, and reheated mixed vegetables...a real disappointment for $29.  5 entrees, no appetizers, no desserts, and 1 shared bottle of the lowest price point wine...$220 before gratuity.  We will not be returning.

NTjEz7uDGpNQqg9APpQcWA.review_text: People wait in long lines. The mixed shrimp, crab and shellfish is too creamy for a Chinese stomach.

gwakmAy1XKzQPl87jXRLVQ.review_text: BEST DAMN AHI EVER.  Let me take a step back.  I am a seafood gal.  My other half is a seafood guy.  Scoma's hit the spot.  I had the seared ahi which was melt-in-your-mouth make you wanna slap  your mama good.  Seriously, I cannot stop talking about it.  The other half had garlic linguini with scallops, shrimp and other assorted fish.  His dish was awesome (slightly less awesome than mine, but I am probably biased).  Our server Lori was awesome.  She was extremely personable and friendly.  I was also impressed with the wine list.  My other half was head over heels for the bread basket.  Warm sourdough? Yes please!  Finally, I liked the vibe.  Even though the decor is a little dated, I liked the white table cloth feel of Scoma.  The location, right next to the water, was also great.  All in all I had a wonderful time here.  Great seafood, always on point with great service.  Check it ou!

16L58WcB-RmvtxDmUHwi6g.review_text: Ambiance: inside decor is simple and a bit dated, but your right on the waterfront and have beautiful views of the bay  Food: delicious! While this place is a bit on the pricier side ($25-30/person) the entrees are phenomenal! Try the calamari as an appetizer and the pistachio crusted salmon with balsamic butter sauce. Portions are generous.  Service: the waiters were very nice, however we waited for our food for over 40 minutes after waiting 20 minutes to be seated.   Bon apetit!

Dd1u-UMqFtIiIDix9fHxwg.review_text: Drove up to Scoma's shortly after Christmas, and we were very disappointed that Scoma's doesn't serve what we considered to be one of their signature dishes - Calamoni ala Anna. The waiter said that they haven't served this calamari steak dish for six months. He was vague about the reason they have stopped serving it. Six or seven of our party of nine would have ordered the dish if it was available.

AS-6FLwDQK6IMW0_dQoJHw.review_text: I've been coming to Fisherman's Wharf for years and have always had my eyes caught by all the tourist traps (I mean, really, who goes to Joe's Crab Shack when you're at Fisherman's Frikkin Wharf?). But I finally found this place and took the wife for her first cioppino. What a great one they had. They do it "lazy" style which means they take the crab meat out of the shell. Since my wife is pregnant, our waitress Sze Sze accommodated us by giving us more salmon instead of swordfish (most places usually just give you cod). The place is expensive but better than all the overpriced tourist traps around here.

-IGAqMovnic1Mj1ZGwYcmw.review_text: The food was ok, but the service was amazing.

gTrG8OHHp0ZvT-xr80o50A.review_text: This is my fourth time here and on previous visits I couldn't stop raving on how good my meal was.  This time I wish we had gone some place else.    I had the Oysters Rockefeller and the Halibut Siciliana. The Oysters were boring and tasted more like cream spinach than oysters.  The Halibut was cooked perfectly but everything else on the plate was a miss; polenta was grainy and undercooked and the vegetables were bland.

zCf_XcFK1jvyba1Y8gicaQ.review_text: Apparently, SF locals enjoy Scoma's. I must say, I do too!  I had, hands down, the most savory bowl of clam chowder I've ever had. Plus, the bits of clam meat had only one or two grains of sand (or whatever gives that crunchy sensation while chewing) which is extra brownie points in my book.  Our lunch consisted of a seafood appetizer sampler, green salad, and the aforementioned chowder. The portions were ample, and the food was delicious (in a crisp, they-must've-got-this-seafood-this-morning kind of way). Heartily recommended for even part-time seafood enthusiasts.  As an aside, the ambiance in there was incredible. From the black and white photos of famous people to the cozy seating arrangements, you get the sense that Scoma's has been doing their thing (and doing it well) for a long time.  Expensive, but in my opinion, completely worth it.

cwqYWgrPD4aLF4HB9ArtGw.review_text: Acceptable, though expensive, seafood at a shack on the Bay.  We hit Scoma's to find cioppino on a recent business trip to SF, after hitting the web to find a decent place that had one.   I like cioppino, and get it anywhere I can.  This one was pretty good, though it's a "Lazy man's cioppino", so there's nothing to crack, and only the clams are in shells, no mussels at all.   Good scallops, good shrimp, large pieces of fish, no chunks of crab (just threads), not much squid, sauce was tasty, but not very thick.   I'd put Brenneke's and even South Point's Oyster Bar over this one, and at $40 it's no bargain.  Others at the table had other things (there's a lot of pasta on the menu, which seems odd for a place on the Bay).  The best prepared dish was the seared Ahi, which wasn't very interesting palate-wise, but was cooked exactly to order.  The interior is acceptable, with lots of "Look who ate here!" shots on the wall.  The exterior is awful... looks like you're eating in a shack.   Oh, and it's a bit of a pain to get to if you're walking the wharf.  3rd star is really just for having an edible cioppino.  2 1/2 otherwise.

pC0DiTh7y91Tr4Ih3c45kg.review_text: I came here with my family and was told to wait about 30 minutes, which we expected. I had the crabcakes and the pasta diplomatica, and the rest of the family had the risotto and the lamb with clam chowders. Overall, the food was great. My pasta was light and delicious. The seafood in the pasta was a lot for me to handle, but for the rest of the family the food was adequately portioned.   The quality of food is okay, not super great or amazing. My family thought that compared to price, the food could have been better. But it's a tourist attraction and I don't blame the restaurant for this. But I do have to compliment their chowder and crab cakes. They were very good and after trying out a lot of the chowders in the area, i can say that this was one of the better ones. same goes for the latter.  The service was also very friendly. He was very attentive, kept good conversation, and was very genuine throughout the meal.   However, the one star I took off was due to something that happened towards the end of the meal. It was not directly related to us, but it was a bit distracting in a bad way. Apparently one of the other waiters could not find the tip that was on a table next to us. The guests had already left and the table was already cleaned. He kept looking for it, and asked one of the "busboys" if he had taken it. I dont really know what happened but the waiter got pretty angry and kept flipping through the tablecloths. Then he said to the "busboy" " youre not getting paid tonight." Maybe I didn't comprehend the full situation, but for him to say that in the middle of where all the guests are that loudly made me frown. He kept saying "where is my money?" And the repetition bothered me and the guests around us.   For a restaurant that is supposed to be renowned for its class and service, it was surprising to hear such things.   But our waiter fortunately was very nice til the end and we were generally satisfied. Would not come back because of the price which we just considered a bit overkill, but I would still recommend it to others. Nice restaurant!!

-2TJaAdxSGnTyy9qGr1z1Q.review_text: Scoma's was recommended to me by a friend, the concierge at the hotel immediately took me for an expert when I mentioned I was planning to have dinner there. The restaurant is cozy and can be a bit cramped when full, thankfully I had an early dinner so I was comfortable.  The waiter was friendly and efficient, my water glass (and wine glass) stayed full. The lobster bisque was heaven and the pasta pomodoro with scallops was delightful. I intended to take a picture of the raspberry cheesecake but consumed it too quickly.  I heard the waiter mention that the steaks are overcooked but the seafood is always perfect - which is fine because it doesn't make sense to order a steak at a place that offers such great seafood!

RrwGZpDaGoF_6FHIYvaSfA.review_text: Absolutely yummy! While in San Fran in Sept during Americas Cup with Mom for a getaway, I took her here for pasta. This is my 3rd visit and each time it's perfect. It was packed and we opted to wait for a table in the bar since it was going to be a long wait. Bar waitress had her hands full w customers but quickly came over and made sure we were settled in with bread and drinks before taking our dinner order. Everything on the menu is excellent, pasta or seafood. Aliotos is another of my favorites down on Pier 45 and they are equally as good but a different more formal type of atmosphere. 5 stars for Scomas!

OaOBbdWvkAXGk3Jralosug.review_text: Prices are within reason for food qualify and location. Located near main wharf area, just walk a short side street for access. Cioppino was best I had on a 2 week trip around Cali, it was extremely large and with a great balance of seafood variety, in a tomato base broth.   All Apps were well received too, and the bar service very accomodating.

ZzHHfnVZn7nWAOzhRlBX3g.review_text: Of course 5 Stars!!!  The food is excellent, if you love seafood, Scoma's Restaurant is for you.  The service is amazing, they really deserve my 5 stars, even more. This place is an example how the service should be, they do know how to treat customers.  Can't wait to visit you again!

UKIbX4yRlGL_92zREMWnwg.review_text: This is your classic old school seafood restaurant. Expect to be thrilled with raw oysters, clam chowder, a large leaf Caesar salad and a dirty martini. Nothing fancy but a wait and two bars to place a cocktail order. It's a great location and view. Know what you are in for and you will be pleased with the result! We walked here from the Kimpton after a long day. Enjoyable but they are certainly not reinventing the wheel!

tmWzlxp-l8Zbo8zN011AZQ.review_text: I lived in the city many years ago and Scoma was my favorite restaurant. It hasn't changed nThe cioppino was great. The bread was delicious.I couldn't ask for a better meal. If you are anywhere near fisherman's wharf for lunch or dinner this is the place to go.

K-YPGA6Wt-n4DQGhJkFKCw.review_text: Decided to eat here after family visiting from out of state had been here years ago and said the food was great.  We were seated in the most cramped dinning room I have ever experienced. We were literally 6 inches away from the other table. Water was brought out and I made a complaint to our server that there was food on my water glass. I was then brought another glass and there was food on that one too! If they can't clean their glassware properly, I'm worried if they clean anything else right...  I ordered the shrimp annuzzi and couldn't be more unimpressed, especially for $30. The pasta was drowning in garlic butter and the rice pilaf was extremely dry. I can make better rice from a box of Rice-A-Roni. The shrimp also tasted very fishy...not fresh at all.  I sadly won't be returning.

CEQsj9pdpmCZ8xY81o60xQ.review_text: We stumbled upon Scoma's while we were out and about one evening; we decided to have lunch the day of our departure.  The experience was really lovely. Signore Salvatore waited on our table and we received top notch service.  We each ordered the prix fixe lunch,of the offerings we selected the stuffed trout: perfectly seasoned and grilled. We look forward to returning to SF and seeing Signore Salvatore again. A side note, perhaps it can be classified as a tourist trap, but we gladly rub elbows with the tourists to dine at such a fine establishment.

agvD4eQC7lP4N9GpNGlUTA.review_text: I met a former co-worker for dinner here on a Wednesday night.  This place was humming along.  Our server was a very nice gentleman named Sal.  He was very attentive and made killer recommendations.  The garlic grilled Dungeness crab is absolutely the best thing I've had in a long time.  Fantastic!  The menu has a good selection of gluten free items (I really pay attention now since my vegan wife is also gluten free).  Atmosphere is really neat and even being sat next to the kitchen, I didn't feel like there was a lot of wait staff traffic in and out.  Great wine selection and their cocktails are really well made.  Had the apple crisp for dessert with a couple of scotches.  It was a greatest and a great place to eat.  Will come back next time I'm in town.  Highly recommended.

oZK2DjCiA-8Xq6utMi4AYA.review_text: 824 reviews already, not much for me to add I suppose.    The food was delicious, the service was fantastic, the prices matched the quality.  I'd definitely go back if I were in San Francisco again.

GeVbqCZ-zOyLNTDOTzphGw.review_text: Best bloody Mary cocktail ever, calimari best eaten hot was amazing, fresh oyster assortment was so good, and the clam chowder is possibly the best I've ever had.   The bread on the table was definately house made or very local.   Great view, wonderful staff, romantic and off the beaten fisherman's wharf path.

HUS74wDi6wf7St1NNr2zuw.review_text: Came to San Fran for the first time and wasn't leaving without a real seafood experience. With Scoma's the task was achieved! We ordered 2 of the dungeness crab roasted in garlic butter. OMG it was SO good! It melted in your mouth and cooked to perfection! I ordered a cup of lobster bisque and it was awesome too. We both left feeling satisfied and having a great seafood experience. Our waiter was so friendly and helpful with the menu. The atmosphere is cozy and quaint. We would definitely go back!

sAN9b5IxryuN9EyqcDyhSA.review_text: This place was so amazing I have to write a review about it! I'm a seafood lover (especially when it comes to shrimp) and my dad said this was the place to go for great seafood. They dont take reservations so I thought my dad and I would have to wait a long time for a table because it was a Friday night. When I walked in I liked the old school atmosphere. To my surprise we were able to be seated right away, which made me very happy. We were starving after the 6 hour drive to San Fran.  Our waiter was very professional and nice. We ordered our drinks and the trio appetizer which was shrimp, calamari, and crab cakes. I was already VERY impressed just by the appetizer it was delicious! I could not decide what to order for my entree because everything sounded soo good. I asked the waiters opinion on the 2 options I was stuck on, and he convinced me to go with the lobster ravioli and white mexican prawns. I was not disappointed when I got this dish, it was even better than the first one!  The sauce on the raviolis was creamy but not too rich to the point where you feel sick after you eat it. The prawns were huge and grilled to perfection. Overall this is probably one of the best dinners I've ever had. I was also satisfied with the service, (I cant stand lousy customer service). The only downside were the drinks were expensive but pretty weak (according to my dad) Whenever I come back to San Francisco I will for sure return here to try the other dishes.

an-ijVpGQxgiOBX9qTBOyQ.review_text: Disclaimer -- the food is FIVE stars!  If I were just reviewing food, I would give this place five stars, hands down.    Came to Scoma's on a Valentine's weekend trip to San Francisco.  Arrived on time for our reservation and were seated right away.  I ordered a French martini, which was perfectly made.  I ordered the lobster bisque to start, while my friend ordered the clam chowder.  Hands down, the lobster bisque is the best I've ever had!  It was absolutely delicious!  The clam chowder was also very good, but I'm more of a lobster bisque kind of girl.  For my entrée, I ordered the Mixed Seafood Grill, which included (already de-shelled) scallops, shrimp and 2 lobster tails, along with steamed vegetables and penne pasta.  All of the seafood was fresh and nicely cooked, and the vegetables had that perfect "crunch" to them, meaning they weren't overcooked.  My friend ordered a whole garlic roasted Dungeness crab.  We both absolutely loved our meals!    The only problem we encountered was with the service.  Although our server was very nice, after we ordered our food, we never saw her again until we finished our meals.  She never stopped by to check how we were enjoying our food or to see if there were any issues.  She asked my friend when we ordered our food if he wanted another drink, but after that, she never asked either one of us again.  My martini glass sat empty for a good while during our meal.  And while I would normally just shrug it off and say she's probably overworked, I can't do that because she was continuously checking on the table next to us.  Now I hate to go here, but we're black, and the couple next to us was an older white couple.  I never want to assume that we receive certain treatment (or lack thereof) because of the color of our skin, but how can I assume anything different?  We were very nice to the server and we were spending a lot of money.  And for the record, we spent more money than the couple next to us (I snuck a peak at their check after they left).  Their total check was $90.  Our entrees only were $90, and we both had soup and drinks on top of that.  At those kinds of prices, it's just unacceptable that our server never checked on us or asked us if we wanted more drinks.  We didn't see her again until after we finished our meals and she came by to ask if we wanted dessert.  By that point, we were so turned off that I wouldn't dare order anything more.  And then it took her another 10 minutes to just bring us our check.    I'm hoping this was just a fluke, but for my one visit to Scoma's, and the amount of money we spent, it was very disappointing to me.

U4IzAxlh05CMCAumDJYNwg.review_text: Good food. Large portions. Upscale restaurant. A San Francisco tradition.

wDQxP1Qc2kdkRTs_FuUJEQ.review_text: I am giving 4 stars because of the service and the desert. The seafood itself was very bland. Nothing remarkable. Good but don't worth the price. We got bread pudding for desert and i have to say I'd come Back there for that. The service was outstanding too.

5_PJKvfCR4DgX8CUmA5A2Q.review_text: We have been coming to Scoma's for almost 20 years & have always enjoyed it immensely.  This time we were a little  disappointed.    We brought our friends here & talked it up like crazy.  We couldn't wait to dig in to our Shellfish Saute Sec.  The waiter put the food down in front of us & that's when the disappointment set in.  The dish used to be huge & full of tons of seafood.  Lots of crab, big shrimp, & plenty of lobster.  Now there's what seems to be half the amount, a lot less mushrooms, & tons of onions.  It used to come with rice, pasta, & steamed vegetables.  Now it comes with this terrible wild rice & grilled root vegetables.  The vegetables were gross, but the seafood part of the dish was still good.     The rest of the meal was good, Lobster Bisque, Caesar Salad & Fried Calamari.  The waiter was very nice, but smelled like cigarettes.    I'm still giving 3 stars because the food was decent.  The last time we came, it was a 5.  Why did they have to change something that was so prefect?  I don't think we'll be back because the food is no longer worth the money.

e-PD38SNj5g49HProyLRpg.review_text: We were so excited to eat here. Everything was great until dessert. Ordered Two desserts to go. We were  charged for both. Got back to hotel but only one was in the take out bag. Boo.

RTvF1w79w9rl7PG8MNJVzg.review_text: Really really awesome!  I had the lobster ravioli and it was amazing.  Totally worth the price! Plate size is really good too, lots of food!

jlKAjPI3hQiAtkXLoq-KZA.review_text: A staple at the wharf. Sat at the bar as there was a wait for a table at lunch. Definitely wise to book a reservation! Enjoyed the beautiful view, the libations and good company at the bar. Had the lobster bisque, oysters rockafeller and the Sea Bass. Everything was amazingly flavorful and fresh. I will be back again to try new things! They have a great prix fixe lunch menu definitely worth checking out. I will definitely be back to enjoy the scenery at night!

jnJf26dkmW6vowC4eh70PQ.review_text: We enjoyed our visit. The service by Ray was excellent. The two person appetizer with calamari, shrimp and crab cakes was good. It would have been better if the crab cakes were lump crab instead of leg meat. The scallops were well prepared and delicious. The risotto with a tomato base was disappointing. Thanks for reading. The Bike Chaplain

RMMK0ukrzf7z7Pf8IY4URg.review_text: Classic Cioppino served Lazy Man Style enables you to kick up your feet and be served. Sometimes the service is a bit lazy too, but you'll be too busying enjoying the fruits of the ocean to care.

xXHLN98SH_wpREdQ76_IQQ.review_text: As a vegetarian, I was pleasantly surprised by Scoma.  I went there for lunch and had a delicious eggplant parmasean.  The restaurant is tucked down a lane on the wharf, and the space was like stepping back into the 1960s -- bow-tied staff and all.  Our table had a view of the Transamerica Pyramid and skyline.  Our server was excellent, particularly in recommending vegetarian options for me.

t9OAdJcdL3suwm0jsAzQEw.review_text: Service was awful this time. The food and prices were still good, given that we took advantage of Dine About Town. However, our server was ridiculously slow and inattentive. He only appeared maybe 4 times, and that was just to take our orders and drop off food. He never stopped by to check on our meal and how we were doing. There were many 5-10 minute gaps in the meal during which we sat there with empty plates. I watched many parties who were seated after us finish their meals and new parties take their place. Those parties then finished their meals at the SAME TIME as us, even though some of them were also doing DAT! I think that service at Scoma's is usually really good, but we just got a very lackadaisical server. I'm not sure why he was so slow, considering the fact that he can make more money in tips if he can move us quicker! And we weren't the only party in his section that suffered. There was a nice couple behind us who literally sat with their menus, ready to order, for about 15 minutes. They looked so bored...  We arrived at 6:40, were told 45 minute wait. We were called and seated by 7:25, so the accuracy of their wait time was much appreciated. However, we didn't get our food until 7:50, and we didn't get out the door until 9:30!!!! Talk about a slow, leisurely meal.  I'll probably still return, but I hope not to get seated in this guy's section again!  Oh and about the food:  - Crab cakes on watercress salad: Very tasty! I liked how the crab cakes were mostly crab and very little filler. I was able to share generous tastings with everyone else at the table.   I also sampled the lobster bisque (very rich!) and a bit of clam chowder. The complimentary sourdough bread is a great utensil for scooping up every bit of the soup!  - Scallops and linguine: You get 5 medium sized scallops on a bed of slightly too overcooked linguine topped with a large dollop of pesto. This dish was actually very large in size, which pleased me. It didn't have a ton of flavor though, and the scallops seemed slightly overdone. I had to add some pepper. I didn't finish this so I had enough to bring home for leftovers. It tasted pretty good the next day, but I was kind of appalled at how oily the sauce was. Must have been the pesto.  The lamp was slightly overcooked for medium rare, but I enjoyed the Parmesan polenta, caramelized onions, and sauteed spinach that were under it.   My dad said his halibut had been precooked and then reheated. He was VERY displeased with the texture, as the reheating was obvious from the mushy crust of the fish. He also said it was too salty.  - Tiramisu and sourdough bread pudding: Tiramisu was really good. The portion size of both was very generous. I liked the tiramisu a lot, but by then I was stuffed. The sourness of the bread and the sweetness of the bread pudding was a bit too much for me, so I didn't finish it.   The raspberry cheesecake with chocolate crust was SO. GOOD. I should have ordered that instead.  One thing I'll give to Scoma's is that they don't skimp on portion sizes, even for Dine About Town selections. And all the other plates I saw emerging from the kitchen were massive as well!  Corkage is $20.

jpvMnToAIQtcw-dNi5EUkw.review_text: I try to hit Scoma's on every other trip to SF.  You have to fight through the tourists on Fisherman's Warf to get here but it's worthwhile.  The best bet is just to order the freshest alternative they have.  Usually this means watching the guys clean the fish in the little house outside the restaurant (on your right as you walk up)  Inside you'll find 70s quaint but ask for a window.  This means that going with parties of 4 or fewer is important, if you want to get a view.  The wine by the glass menus is respectable.

SBgBRz4ONPacMb7VfrWhxw.review_text: Service was slow, but they were still able to accommodate us early. The food was pretty good, but bland and the roast vegetables were soggy and flavorless. Steak was more on the well side than medium. Pricey, but a nice pier experience for the atmosphere.

xRbBt5MVKZ5-_8HhhfI26g.review_text: A restaurant hidden away in the back of fisherman's wharf. I heard this place has great oyster based on the recommendation of my cab driver. I wouldn't have found this place if it wasn't for the recommendation. The average age of the customer is in their old 50's. so it's a older crowd kinda place. I think you'll have more fun eating outside where all the buzz are happening if younger than 50.   This was my 4th meal of the day (it's about 5:00pm at this time), so I only crabbed a half dozen oyster and a cup of clam chowder. For $18.00, you get 6 oysters on your plate. It's definitely not the best oyster I have, but satisfy the craving at that time. The claim chowder is not special at all either; just like any other claim chowder.   Now, on to the service here, it SUCKS. It's an old old restaurant trying to "pretend" they're a high class restaurant; trying a little too hard to be an expensive restaurant. The average age of the waiter is around 50 years old too, which suits the average age of the customers. The host; however, were younger (early 20's). They talked and talked and talked among themselves the whole time rather than informing their customers why they had to wait so long for a table. I waited 20 minutes at 4:00pm for a table when more than half of the restaurant is empty.   Tip: Don't come here, no need to come here. It's boring and suffocating in here. Much more fun sitting on the busy street eating and watch the crowd.

_apCOddyBZBImQgGu3Hm7A.review_text: Found this place on Yelp when we were walking around. Cute little place tucked behind all of the other larger businesses (which we really liked). We were seated right away, had some deliciously fluffy bread, and had a decent view of the water. Our waiter, Salvatore, was really nice and professional (old school waitstaff).  We ordered a Hot Sampler Trio for Two ($26); it was a mix of Calamari Fritti, Rock Shrimp Scampi, and Crabcakes. BF had a Bloody Mary ($10).   The sampler was really tasty. The calamari fritti was perfectly crispy, the Crabcakes held together but were deliciously moist, and the shrimp scampi was perfectly cooked (and the sauce was great for bread dipping!) BF really liked his Bloody Mary as well!  Overall, great pricey little spot tucked away from the hustle and bustle of the wharf. We'd definitely be back.

asL1d04xS3y8YQtU5ota-g.review_text: Clam chowder with sour dough bread. So good. It's the best I've found in San Francisco. The portions are so large we usually split so my wife and daughter had the seafood cannelloni and they loved it. I had the pasta fisherman style with crab, shrimp, and mushrooms in a white sauce. It was pretty good. The service was really good and the server was nice. I love this place and we always try to go to this place every time I come to San Francisco.

fwJWf9dvUbZ0aRKcqkCB7A.review_text: Had lunch here after picking up some crab right down the street at alioto lazio fish company. I ordered the swordfish and it was excellant! Mom had the pacific rockfish, hers was delicious to. Both were cooked to perfection. However it was served with roasted root vegetables, and a wild rice, barley, bean, quiona medley which were not so good so if this is offered to you, id pass and ask for something else. Took dad home some lazy mans chippino and it was ok, far from the best weve had. Overall this is a great restaurant you just gotta know what to order. I highly recommend the swordfish piccata!

JQTmEjST0R_qgpev-879fA.review_text: Being new to San Francisco, this was one of the first restaurants I visited, and I was not disappointed.  The service was excellent. I tried fried calamari, grilled swordfish and fresh crab legs. I have to say that the crab legs were definitely the best part for me.

J9HamWsxKorlPGUAXy-M9Q.review_text: Scoma's can be easily missed even with Google Maps navigating on your iPhone.  Be prepared ahead of time to avoid circling around an already busy tourist area.  Parking is somewhat limited so valeting it would be your best bet.  When you enter, you'll want to have that nice view of the bay since the large glass windows won't block the nice view.  Onto the food!  For starters, you'll want to grab the infamous hearty man's cioppino.  It's stewy and hearty so be careful you don't tap out only on the first course.  With the complimentary bread, it's easy to fill up since the bread goes so well with that tomato soup base.  If you want to play it safe, split the cioppino with your date.  The other thing to try is the lobster bisque.  It's a love or hate thing so if you're not a fan of bisque, then don't get it.  I'm a fan of both bisque and lobster so it was a great starter for dinner.  It tastes like I'm sucking out the lobster entrails from it's body/shell/carapace!  The crab cakes were pretty good but small.  I wished they were just a tad bit bigger to be satisfying.  I won't go into detail for the main entrees since the appetizers were pretty good and talking further would ruin the good vibe already built up.  Only thing I can say is that the entrees are mediocre compared to the appetizers/soup.  Summary of items ordered: * Cioppino * Lobster bisque * Crab cakes * Lamb t-bone * Yellowfin tuna * Tiramisu * Chocolate brownie with vanilla bean ice cream

1CLFB9Zos3kGz1Xuj2eyww.review_text: I absolutely love love love this restaurant. The food is always delicious & the service is always 100% perfect. We've been coming here for easily 8+ years -- birthdays, anniversaries, random family dinners, date nights...  You can't go wrong with the Manila Clams, Garlic Bread, Fried Calamari & of course the absolute best Clam Chowder as your starters.   We always go with a steak, fish & pasta as our main entrees. Always yummy too!   By dessert, we are way too stuffed.   Note: make reservations, otherwise you're waiting.

f4chSy9hAc1dampwEuuU0Q.review_text: AMAZING! The best hands down! Got calamari, salmon and chowder. Best I've ever had of all pricey but no that going in was worth every penny

5j65nptHTM7E5G-Lclyz8Q.review_text: Scoma's was once my favourite, and the hidden gem of the Fisherman's Wharf... I stumbled upon it in 1999 and was completely blown away.  Fast forward 15 years, and I can honestly say that it's time for me to move on to another seafood restaurant.  We ordered a Caesar Salad, and the Hearts of Romaine Salad. The Caesar Salad was mediocre at best. I don't think salads are a strong suit there in general, so beware.  For our mains, we ordered the Fettuccine with Smoked Salmon and Shrimp... a total disappointment. I had this dish back in 1999, and at that time, the Salmon was HUGE along with the Shrimps. Over time, the Salmon became small strips, and the Shrimps were non-existent and tiny.  I expected the same kinds of amazing dishes that once wow'd me then, but Scoma's was certainly showing it's age, and times have changed. I was incredibly disappointed with my experience.  The only reason I gave it an extra star was only for the fairly prompt service. Otherwise, as much as I hate to do this, but it only deserves a one-star...  feel terrible doing it though.

l35uoedk9e740vl9fwYRqg.review_text: I didn't realize that this was a must go to place while visiting San Francisco.  But thanks to Yelp and some friends I found my way there. We got there on the early side for lunch and had to wait for our entire party to be seated even though the place was empty.  It would of been nice to have been seated right away but obviously they don't do things that way here.   Once we were seated the service was good.  We all ordered the Crab Louie Salad and it was a huge salad and they really pile on the dungeness crab.   I would definitely recommend this place for lunch or dinner.

fUSsb6zgdAWAAYxvTapr2g.review_text: My family has been coming to Scoma's since I was young. Every time I am in San Francisco I make sure to stop by here. Normally I order the lobster bisque and shrimp louie, but I was feeling adventurous on my most recent visit here and got the Cioppino...beyond amazing! Pretty pricey so a good special occasion restaurant, but I always make sure to recommend Scoma's to any friends visit SF. Food, service, ambiance, and the view are all phenomenal!

XRE7Np7TswBOrOnokO2nTA.review_text: Seriously people!?!? If you're allergic to any kind of seafood then don't go to a seafood restaurant!! DUH! I think you deserved the anaphylaxis because Scomas is the best seafood EVER. I would wait hours for this delicious meal. The waiters are top notch and treat you like royalty. The Saute Sec is to die for and the Crab salad with both thousand island and blue cheese is out of this world. The bread is probably the best bread you could ever get for free at a restaurant. The cheesecakes are all amazing and beautifully presented with a delicious drizzle of raspberry sauce. :-O

swmrfBnaqU0nyJ3pFBfNgQ.review_text: Playing tourist in my hometown and wanted good clam chowder.  It would have to be at Scoma's.  It wasn't crowded at all which was amazing.  I had a cup of the ocean filled clam chower, $9 and regretted not ordering the bowl and just having that for lunch. Got the fried calamari appetizer which is enough for 3 -4 persons, $14.  Couldn't even finish the entire plate and took it home which was devoured by Jr. Yelper.  Hubby had the open faced flank steak sandwich, $17.  Slices of steak over a garlic toast with a small salad and fries.  The fries were nice and crispy.  I thought the fried calamari was a bit too oily, needed to be drained a bit longer.    The waiter - Jean, was really friend and checked on us continuously. Service is always great here.  Forget the other touristy restaurants right on the main Wharf walkway.  Scoma's is where the food is especially the clam chowder - full of potatoes, clams in a thick, creamy broth.

niKu4se6xtf-ctlm0udr1w.review_text: Solid seafood fare.  Nothing spectacular.. I had the lobster ravioli which was very nice with good portion.  The clams were solid.  The tuna was a bit more cooked than i expected.   Oysters were great.  Appetizer platter was a good choice, we got to try calamari, crab cakes and some kinda shrimp thing.  Overall the food and experience is pretty good, to be expected by the pricing.  If you're looking to impress or have a nice dinner, i would recommend this establishment.

j7Ew20Kh33lFEaUXW1rGNw.review_text: You can tell this place has been around forever, there are lots of celebrity pictures on the wall but I'm not sure how many of them are still alive! The view is good, you see right into the harbor. As others have said its probably overpriced but you're in SF.   The sourdough bread basket before the meal is excellent. I had the blackened salmon with mashed potatoes and vegetable of the day. The salmon was perfect, had some spice and the perfect balance between overlooked and too juicy for my liking. I will order this again. The mashed potatoes were good too. I wasn't a fan of the veggie, I don't like broccoli or cauliflower and the zucchini was a little overcooked.  If you are looking for a place with history that's on the wharf but not a glorified chain restaurant come check out Scoma's.

dfb8gr9dCLGZX0_HzfauRg.review_text: This was referred to from a seat mate in first class who's a local of SFO and he seemed to be a fairly well traveled gentleman and knows great food :)  With the bar set at ultimate high from previous night's dinner at Gary Danko, I knew it would be pretty tough to make a comparison as both are of the opposite spectrum. GD is a more upscale/dressy ambiance and this is suppose to be a bit more on the casual end but just as amazing in terms of food grade. We had a rsvp for 8:30, car serviced dropped us off at 8:25 and upon walking in, we were greeted with a sea of people hovering around where the reception area would be which I thought could use a little bit more organization but besides the point...proceeded to check in for our reservation and then we had to find a space to stand and wait for our names to be called over the intercom til our table was ready which was a good 15 minutes wait so I suggest getting there about 15 minutes prior to your rsvp, maybe more on a busy night (mind you this was a Monday night rsvp). So the seating promptness for a reservation was sub part at best and at this point I was just hoping for the meal to compensate for that and hopefully live up to the hype....IT DID!!!  The lobster bisque was delish. For my main course I went for the night's mixed grill option of 3 different types of uber fresh fish and jumbo shrimps on a bed of roasted vegetables and a hefty serving of mashed potato seasoned to perfection and a smoked salmon romoulade that was just soooo orgasmic. ..yes I said it.. which also paired really well with the bottle of WillaKenzie Estate pinot noir wine we had.  The serving was definitely hefty and filling that I couldn't even finished the rest of my meal. Overall, the meal definitely is worth the hype. Can't say much for the dessert menu as we never made it that far :)

TZ9mfycN7WU4MtYJQtQxfg.review_text: The King Salmon was melt in your mouth AMAZING!! Definitely glad I took the waiter's recommendation! The garlic mashed potatoes weren't too garlicky and the vegetables were so fresh!

jyV_D39wFTBxaQ6Un_OXWQ.review_text: Very good crab but the appetizers were just ok. The service was great but it was a little overpriced. The clam chowder was very fishy. It was a very romantic place though.

PzzcjpzzanDDhxsR9OlmLg.review_text: We came here after multiple people said to check it out (cab driver, another couple at a bar, yelp) and it was alright. We made reservations which is a must as the place attracts a large crowd. Has a good location right on the pier so if you are lucky to get a table near a window, its fun to gaze at the docked boats. Wait staff was definitely old school which matched the decor in the restaurant but friendly and informative.   Our meals were good and a hefty. We definitely were not blown away as all the hype made it seem, but overall a good place and worth checking out for a good seafood plate.

RpC1JbCcl7iMUWosF5EsWg.review_text: Lobster bisque was amazing and so were the crab cakes. Great location on pier with a great atmosphere. Not ridiculously expensive.

G-QM2_56Fi-iDyUIfhN5ng.review_text: Not good.  Scallops just okay.  Prawns were tough.  Wouldn't go back.

lv3_Ua42m9h-77SxZ0ntlA.user_location: Griffith Park/Los Feliz, Los Angeles, CA
lv3_Ua42m9h-77SxZ0ntlA.review_text: Amazing! You must come here if you're in town. The seafood was the most amazing I've ever had. All fish is prepared the way you'd like. I got the scallops and couldn't believe how well they were prepared. Cooked to perfection. I came with 3 other people who all raved about their meals as well. Everyone ordered something different too! I'd definitely suggest making a reservation though, as the wait was about an hour and 15 during their dinner hour without one.

8B4LYEZHc6Vw2BsqDHgnvg.review_text: My fiancée  family has been going to this restaurant for over 30 years to enjoy different dishes, but mainly for the Lazy Ciopinno. We went here as usual this last Saturday, and found out that the old. traditional recipe for Ciopinno was recently changed. Unfortunately, not for the best ... My fiancée who was so loyal to this place for so many years said that there is no really reason to come back:(

xsq_bpGYLoPpuzUTDbifDw.review_text: Service was good, food was so-so.  The garlic-roasted crab didn't have as much flavor as I was expecting.  Nice that it's on the water, but the view isn't as good as some of the other places in the Wharf.

s8j7xv_fO3XKQWrcSQs3uQ.review_text: Everyone in my party loved their plates!! Excellent food!! Specially the salmon with lobster ravioli, mixed seafood and lobster! The service wasn't that great but probably we just has bad luck with the waiter. Defenitely a must try in SF!

9SoO6g3AT7UHSaIRtwr_-g.review_text: 4.5 Stars  First let me say that there was many things that were not going in our favor in regards to eating here.  Like I do in many cities I visit I like to ask the locals the best place to eat.  Many times I get "tourist" places, but sometimes I get some good unique places.  This is definitely the former but the location and the building was pretty cool and made it look like a place that I may have never been before.   First, I don't think we (and my wife for sure) were looking for a "fine dining" place to eat.  More of just a good seafood joint.  When my wife saw the menu and the prices next to them she nearly fell off her chair.  She was so upset with how expensive it was she literally started crying.  I; however, was just looking for what I wanted to eat from what looked like a pretty righteous seafood place.    This is where I look like a bad husband (but I partially redeem myself later I promise). I ordered the cioppino and the lobster bisque...she was so pissed off she ordered nothing.  I had little remorse...but I digress...  The whole time while the food was being prepared I was consoling her and assuring her that we were on vacation and we can go out to a nice meal.  When the food came I split everything I ordered with her (GO ME) and she had nothing to say but positive things about the food (However, when she looks back at this place she still doesn't think it was worth it).   I guess this is the part where I actually review the food (c'mon I had to set the mood). The cioppino was the best I have ever had.  The broth was very flavorful, but didn't take away from the freshness of the seafood.  It felt like there was literally pounds of seafood in this dish too.  The size of each piece of seafood was very impressive - and you can almost justify the price because of that.  The lobster bisque was great as well.  So yeah, its quite pricey (and crowded), but I would go back there to get the cioppino no questions asked, but I may need to sign the deed of my car over to get it.

eSlDbkIXnPhJB1NH553zUg.review_text: The San Francisco landmark is good for lunch. We had a nice lunch on Father's Day. The lunch menu is a decent value. We enjoyed the French bread, clam chowder, seafood pasta and the catch of the day. The dinner menu looks too expensive for the ambiance and quality of food !  The service was nothing special. The steamed vegetables are average.

p3sTKtdZp5WriTptjd5XpA.review_text: Everything about this place was underwhelming. 4 stars with over 1000 reviews must mean a great place right? Nope - one of the rare occasions that Yelp led me astray.  The restaurant was an average looking building, average decor with rickity cheap tables and chairs. Their highly rated lobster bisque was very mediocre with zero traces of real lobster. The calamari had way too much breading for how thinly sliced the actual squid was. The $17 shrimp cocktail with "jumbo" shrimp came with 6 average sized shrimp. While their fish was fresh, they made zero effort into cooking a good meal with it. We got the mixed platter with (teeny pieces of) swordfish, salmon and halibut. Each fish tasted exactly the same because it was purely just grilled - no spices, no sauces, just literally plain pieces of fish. It really says something about a seafood restaurant when my favorite thing of the meal was the mashed potatoes. Overall, just a big tourist trap getting you to pay double/triple the price for measly portions of very bland, generic food.  I don't mind shelling out for a good meal but when I spend more than $50 on dinner per person, I expect the quality of the food to match the price tag. I'm assuming most places around Fisherman's Wharf have fresh fish and I'd much rather go a chain like Joe's crab shack or Bubba Gump for a more fun experience at a fraction of the cost.

F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw.review_text: Scoma's was pretty much everything I expected out of a seafood restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf.  That is both good and bad in terms of the whole dining experience where you'll know that the seafood is fresh, but because you're in the touristy part of town, service can be mediocre and prices are much higher than other similar restaurants in other parts of the city. I started off with a cup of Clam Chowder and got to try the Crab Cakes shared with the table.  The Chowder was good and loaded with clams.  Likewise, the Crab Cakes from were loaded with crab and were pretty plump and breaded nicely. For my main course I was in the mood for Scallops, so I went with the Shrimp and Scallops alla Gannon --  bit.ly/UeiuOO Well, there's not much to say about this one.  It's simply pan seared scallops and shrimp with steamed veggies and mashed potatoes.  It was good, but it wasn't mind-blowing enough for me.  At least it took care of my craving for Scallops. Our server, while he got the job done, was pretty unenthusiastic.  His tone of voice was pretty ho-hum and sounded like he was just trying to get through the service with  no enthusiasm whatsoever.  It was kind of a shame, but there were no issues with our orders and we were checked on regularly. I don't know what much else there is to say about Scoma's.  The seafood was definitely fresh and the portion sizes were pretty generous, but I thought the food was pretty overpriced for what you get.  Well, the bright side is that they have plenty of tables, so if you have a big group to feed and happen to be around the Fisherman's Wharf area, Scoma's would be good enough to handle that.

-g_eXoAVe3fIUPJlIYvw6w.review_text: Extremely disappointed. Seafood was not fresh. Steamed clams undercooked, crab cakes bland, Lobster Thermidor not browned properly. Coffee burned, not fresh. Would not recommend to anyone. No excuse for an old school restaurant. What has happened? With all the great restaurants in SF, there is no excuse!

bwZn44lANLGt4zI4jRiQcA.review_text: Hands down the freshest seafood I've had in the US.  My family tried the swordfish, the shrimp & scallops, crab risotto, and the lobster ravioli... All were to die for.

0Od3PvCzzVfbX-RDR7G1rA.review_text: So gross overpriced tourist trough. I can't believe some of the 4 and 5 star reviews..!?!?!? Mediocre food (and that is being generous), scuzzy cheap atmosphere. I ordered the sand dabs that were slimy while somehow still being overcooked. Eew!   I got dragged here by my ever-desperate-to-be-classy stepmother...who thinks class is wearing coordinated denim 'outfits' and triple dangle earrings on each ear.   SF natives or long-time residents would never, dream of eating at Fisherman's Wharf, but I was way too tolerant and acquiesced.

saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q.review_text: San Francisco Treat!  This should be their moniker, not that darn Rice-a-Roni!  There's not many restaurants that draws both locals and tourists alike.  My friends invited me to dinner here on a Friday night.  The valet parking is free, but please remember to tip your valet person as a courtesy.  This is a "no reservations" dining spot, so it pays to show up early, especially on weekends.  We waited about ten minutes, which gave me time to study their menu posted outside the front door.  We were led past the bar area to an upper level dining room and seated at a cozy booth.  I had a clear view of the parked fishing boats that reminded me of childhood PAL salmon fishing trips.  My dilema was to choose between the Cioppino and the three-course prix fixe menu for $39.95.  I chose the latter and opted for the following choices: Appetizer 1) Double Play (1/2 portion of Caesar's salad and 1/2 cup portion of New England Clam Chowder) - Salad was tasty and perfectly seasoned.  The clam chowder was creamy with small clam chunks.  Decent, but not my personal best.(yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp…) Entree 2) Grilled Giant Freshwater Prawns with Linguini - Two nicely grilled prawns topping a generous linguini portion mixed with tomato chunks, olive oil, and pesto.  Liked that the pesto was spooned to one section so I could mix it to my liking. (yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp…) Dessert 3) Tiramisu and Bread Pudding - The Tiramisu was rich and creamy and the bread pudding was cleaner tasting and gooey.  Good contrast in flavors here. It was a mixed crowd with after-work co-workers, tourist couple and families, and older couples.  For those who grew up in the City, it's a bit of a Back to the Future experience.  Our waitress was efficient and friendly and the staff made sure our water glasses were full.  The valet was extremely nice and parked my vehicle near the entrance.  Regarding the Cioppino, they also offer a "Poor Man's" version where they remove the shells from the crab (it's pricier which goes against my thrifty conscience).  The cuisine is a nice mix of North Beach and seafood, packaged in a touristy neighborhood.  The business celebrated a recent 45th anniversary last week and gave an additional $5.00 on the above menu.  Darn, didn't make it back in time to catch that discount.

P0tcGzp-3RIT0t2fAry3vQ.review_text: Having been introduced to Scoma's in 1998 by a SF colleague of mine on my 1st trip to the city, I've made it a point to visit each of the next two times I travelled there.  On this, my 4th trip to SF I tried several times to get in by using the Open Table link on their Yelp site, but the times were either too late or too early, so I resigned to the fact we wouldn't be going to Scoma's. I found our last full day, a Monday, we had availability so I found a 4:00 time and worked our schedule for the day around it.  Glad I did. We started at the bar 1st for an early cocktail (it's 6:30 back east where we live!), my wife having a blue cheese stuffed olive martini, and I opted for a glass of Zin.  My wife raved about the martini and my wine was quite tasty. When we were ready, we were seated at a table with a view of the back dock. Nothing overly scenic, but better than looking at a wall.  We order a bottle of wine, and while uncorking it the server went over the menu, offering  her opinions and suggestions.  We usually share dishes so we can experience more tastes, so we ordered the Lobster Bisque and the Oyster Rockefeller alla Scoma to start.   We decided on the Mixed Seafood Grill and the Alaskan Halibut Siciliana for our entrée's.  The Bisque was good (I'm not a big bisque fan anyway, so 'good' is a compliment) but the Oysters were out of this world.  Made me wish I didn't have to share them. Yummy. Then came the entrée's;  Both were delicious.  The Mixed Grill was plentiful, so much so that my wife couldn't finish it all, but did manage to leave no shrimp or lobster behind.  My Halibut Siciliana was so flavorful I didn't leave anything behind. Our server (change of shift, seamless) tried to temp us with desert, and he was successful.  I judge places based on their Tiramisu against my favorite back home (I won't give away the name of that place) and considered whether I wanted to risk souring my overwhelmingly favorable opinion of  the early evening's dining experience, but decided to go for it.  He also told us of a Chocolate Torte that wasn't on the menu, so we order that too.  The Tiramisu exceeded my expectations and the Torte just made it hard to declare a winner, so we called it a tie. What a wonderful dining experience. The food and the service are top notch. So glad we decided to fit this into our schedule. We had some great food during our week in SF, but I think we saved our best experience for last!

TQ42P2aYySg7PMJi37okaA.review_text: This is my go-to seafood restaurant in the city, and one locals and other chefs go to. The others in the Wharf are tourist traps.  Get the Cioppino altho all the fish dishes are fresh.  Pricey, but worth it, unlike the other ripoffs nearby.

g4R634Rgk_ivLeVJ8byupg.review_text: I was here during Fleet Week and I was in uniform. Therefore, I was treated "above average" during my visit. Beers were on the house as we waited 45 mins for our table. (Get the Liberty Ale.) The restaurant hooked us up with a cup of the chowder and it was definitely one of the best chowders I had. Chunky, thick and cream broth with flavor. The CLAMS were lacking though. I was going to order the Petrale, until I was told it was breaded and fried. The waiter, Andrew (who was awesome), recommended the Halibut. It was bar far the best seafood dish in the Bay Area. BY FAR! Service was great. One big negative: a bit price. $30+ for the halibut.  My boss had the filet mignon. He could've easily cut that steak with a butter knife. Very juicy too. Good job Al Scoma. RIP.

ZEGyf9O7GyYzJOqbhbSY9g.review_text: A local recommended this restaurant to us and we are glad he did. It is tucked away a bit so unless you were looking for it you probably wouldn't find it. It sits right on the water and has a "rustic" feel to it.   The wait staff was friendly and professional, and the food was quite good. The clam chowder was a little thick for my liking, but the entrees were fresh and perfectly prepared. We had the Atlantic halibut and Washington salmon, both of which were caught fresh that day.

tkAjiVsQEhcVjc-0CKzcNg.review_text: Great combination of touristy San Francisco seafood but with quality good enough for locals.  I have been here several times and this was my best experience.  Started with the clam chowder, an old standby that they do well.  Normally I have the cioppino because I am in SF and have to but this time I had the Shrimp and Scallops alla Gannon.  Other than the fact it comes with two starches (rice and potatos) it was great, a tasty, butter garlic sauce and perfect shrimp and scallops.

KqynXAy4trNllprNCZqA9Q.review_text: I came here for the first time the other day and had a great experience. The lobster bisque and garlic roasted dungeness crab were delicious. However, our favorite part of the meal was dessert - Jack Daniel's bread pudding. It is TO DIE FOR! So amazing that we came back two days later just for dessert because we couldn't stop thinking about it. A little pricey, but worth it. We plan to go back soon and try their prix fixe lunch menu which looked good.

yX6miszwwodkYGLBg7UEmQ.review_text: Classic San Francisco restaurant in a touristy area.  The drinks and food are pretty good, but not epic or great, but was worth the visit.  One of the great bonuses here is the parking as they have free valet parking in a part of town that can be very difficult to find a parking spot, so this is a great choice for visitors with a car.

lZHn-ZDHbwaxXCz7FqP2pw.review_text: Yeah it's in a tourist trap section of town but the food is great  I've been coming to Scoma's on Fisherman's Wharf for more that twenty five years. Al  Scoma passed a few years ago, but the staff carry on his legacy.   They make a wide variety of seafood and Italian dishes, but I prefer the Petrale Dore, a Sole fish sauted in a light batter.  Some of the staff, like Joey, my waiter on my most recent visit have been there for decades, so the service is spot on. On of my dining companions didn't know what dish she wanted so described in general that she wanted to eat crab but didn't want a messy, time consuming whole crab. Joey brought her a Dungeness Crab Risotto that she really enjoyed.   On the down side, the wait can be long on weekends and they don't take reservations. They do offer valet parking.   Have a drink, look at the view and enjoy your meal.

Zwh3xuj4XA8d-1ydC5QV9g.review_text: We were a group of five traveling together and everyone loved this restaurant...the setting, the waiter, and THE FOOD! We were there on a Wednesday evening, off season, so there was no wait, but if necessary we would wait the next time just to eat here again.

uhk0McY6qtKHIaqrXw4d3A.review_text: Very promising venue, yet very disappointing food.   This place has all the great clues for a "find". You pass many other restaurants in a tourist mecca on your way walking there. It is just slightly off the beaten path. It looks very unassuming from the outside. The interior looks like it was hip when Frank Sinatra was in his 20's and it hasn't been updated, making you think it is so great that they don't need to modernize the decor. "Yes" you think, "I have found a secret gem!"  Sadly, the food disappoints. The wait time for a table, the dated interior, and the inferior view are just predictions of your mediocre meal. Bland, predictable, and easily surpassed by other restaurants in the same area....our favorite is the Franciscan a few blocks away.

Baow2ccooo19HoCO7cNXbw.review_text: Sits by itself on one of the quieter piers, tucked away safely from the hordes of tourists with their shopping bags full of fake jade and Chinatown souvenirs that were made in Japan.  Once inside, you can't help but feel like a SF insider.  The long bar at the front can get a little crowded with diners waiting to be seated.  Our wait at prime time on a Thursday was 40 minutes, but the bartenders were both busy and attentive, so no problem.  My Clams (in the shell) over Linguine with white sauce was the best I'v had in recent years.  Zero grit.  If you're a clam lover you know how rare that is.  My dining companion was extermely pleased with her salmon.  You must have the bread.  It's San Francisco after all.  The wait staff were polished professionals.

zaF2tOkKtw_EMr5K7mgGDQ.review_text: Went with the "wild " salmon.  Veggies and garlic mash potatoes.  Visiting San Fran from Dallas and I had better Salmon at Red Lobster and much better priced.  Bland fish.  Undercooked veggies.  Over seasoned potatoes.  Disgusting.

F262q88zc7zsdEeNCzcA0A.review_text: Popped into Scoma's on a warm Thursday evening with some friends from out of town in an effort to avoid some of the more 'touristy' locales. I called to make a reservation on our walk over but they were fully booked so they recommended walking in as it looked like they'd be able to accommodate our group of six with a 15 - 20 minute wait. We were pleasantly surprised to find that they actually had a table for us immediately when we walked into the restaurant.   Our server greeted us promptly and got us set up with a round of cocktails that we enjoyed while we decided what to order.   The beau and I shared a mixed green salad to start. For my main I ordered one of their daily catches, broiled (Halibut) and he ordered a bowl of their Clam Chowder. Mine was served with a side of seasoned veggies and a walloping scoop of roasted garlic mashed potatoes. His chowder was jam packed full of fresh clams and the bowl sized portion wasn't too gigantic.   The rest of the table ordered a Wild Caught Salmon entree and a Shrimp & Smoked Salmon Linguine which looked amazing.   Everything was well prepared and I was a big fan of how fresh the fish was!   I don't know that I'd race back to Scoma's any time soon because it does feel a bit touristy (and maybe a little dated -- don't pop in expecting some super innovative gastronomic-hipster menu), but for being on the Wharf you can expect a good fresh meal, attentive servers and a classy ambiance.

PBCG_JpmsVNHoU6y-ojFfg.review_text: Went for a last minute meal, sat at the bar, Steve was awesome, oysters Rockefeller... JAM!!!

oBpWAd-xV0_7xX0ZLYd8GA.review_text: Didn't even make it to the table. Walked in at about 11:05 (apparently they don't serve food till 11:30). What looked like a manager and a server stood about 3 feet from us and had a casual conversation which each other for about 3 minutes without even looking at us or acknowledging us. There was another woman who walked in at the same time we did, we assume a local regular. This woman made a comment about the hostess MAYBE getting to us eventually. Then the hostess popped up out of the hostess stand and made a rude comment to the woman and rolled her eyes.  She told us she could seat us but they don't serve food till 11:30. We said NOPE and went elsewhere. Talk about rude hospitality. I don't care how good the food is supposed to be...with unfriendly service like that as soon as you walk in the door, I'm moving on.

43gffDcxSzpNoI0Py2BU9A.review_text: As if the excellent food weren't enough, the customer service is Old World sophisticated, Our waiter was a delight and did not steer us wrong with the entree suggestions.  I had the salmon and shrimp pasta.  For a person who NEVER eats pasta, I splurged this evening and am so glad I did.  It was phenomenal. Though pricey, if you are looking for that one nice/pricey meal for your trip, Scoma's is a can't miss.

cCTUFH4DKPuSuFhbIIcbzw.review_text: I've been coming here for years and I love this place. Its much more casual than you'd expect.   I always used to get the lobster (never fails. :) cioppino is really good tiramisu is sooo good all their appetizers are really good too  i had the salmon recently. it was really bland. i was so disappointed since ever other experience I've had here was so much better. Its ok, guess you cant win everyday.. I'll be back to try something else next time...

Do2_cOmcD75d9yv70lW6TQ.review_text: Whoa! That's what comes to mind whenever I think about Scoma.  I've been fortunate to try out a whole bunch of restaurants and good eats.. but only once in awhile does a restaurant make an everlasting impression in my head.. and Scoma is one of the places that has done so.  I had the Dungeness Crab Risotto... one of the most delicious things I've ever had in my life.  The risotto was so rich in flavors and well balanced.  The amount of Dungeness crab was great too.  A friend of mine got the whole roasted cracked dungeness crab.  It was cooked amazingly with olive oil, garlic, and fresh lemon.  I was impressed with both dishes, and I'm excited to try out other menu items in the future!

GupZ7GAIqdiaoRm_PyMdSA.review_text: I had the pasta with salmon and shrimp + creamy sauce. My gf had the baked salmon and lobster on ravioli. My pasta was meh but she was very satisfied with her dish. Considering how classy the restaurant is, the price was okay. The restaurant is conveniently located on the dock so it was surrounded by water and all the boats. Romantic night, if not for an argument we had by the end of the dinner :( but the server was nice enough to joke around and lighten up the mood, so +1 star for that :D

jF8nR8Iqhq7oHOl1m_yXyg.review_text: ABOVE AND BEYOND THE HYPE!!!!!!  Amazing. So glad this was much better than anticipated. Very cool inside. Old celeb photos on the wall are very cool. Staff is beyond professional. Timing, personality and just impressive. Extra points that they serve their own branded mini tabasco bottles with the meal.  Started off with raw clams on the half shell and some corn and crab chowder. Clams were the best I've ever had. Even the cocktail sauce stands out here. The chowder was a little bland for what I was expecting. I'm from Boston and a snob with chowder, so I'll let it go. Now the cioppino, is best of the best. It was beyond perfect and can't imagine anyone that can ever make it better. When I'm requesting my last meal, it will be Scoma's cioppino.

VgGeJDT-HUq60HwjMMzJcw.review_text: terrible experience, nowhere close to three stars, service is ok, but the food, terrible. Both me and my wife have had stomach ache and diarrhea 10 mins after the appetizer (and we haven't eat anything else that day). chef didn't come and explain, we were still being charged for the full course.  (review written by zmacs in 2012)

uQifz4CeUJ0Uyn69BRi3bQ.review_text: Came here just recently and had the greatest time! This place was the icing o the cake for my SF weekend. Food and service are great, a little pricey but you get what you pay for. Our server, Laurie was wonderful! Lobster ravioli was out of this world and the dessert was on the house as it was my girlfriends birthday. Tip- come a little later (we went around 9:15 on a Sunday) so you don't have wait for a table. Restaurant is a little down further on pier 47, I would totally come back to this place!

s2o_JsABvrZVm_T03qrBUw.review_text: It was a grand meal to finish off our one day in San Francisco!  I began with a bowl of a superior creamy and luscious New England Clam Chowder, followed by a Mixed Greens Salad with light Thousand Island Dressing.  The greens were mixed with rich red tomato slices, Black Olives, beets, and Radicchio.  Moist Sourdough Bread and butter added a splendid touch to these preliminaries.  Server Waiman over-peppered the salad, but otherwise provided great service, including new silverware for each course.  He dissuaded me from ordering Potatoes au Gratin, and gave me Sauteed Spinach as a vegetable accompaniment to my chosen entree of grilled Petrale Dore Sole.  The delicate fish was fork tender, golden, lightly battered, and super-tasty adorned with some drips of heavenly ultra-fine and mild homemade Tartar Sauce.  Also on the plate was some oily Penne, which did not have much flavor.    Diane very much liked her Lobster Newburg made with Provolone Cheese.  And,  both of our entree portions were quite large.  While dining, we had a nice view of moored fishing fleet vessels just outside.    An excellent seafood dinner from start to finish!  Expensive, but worth it!

iw7k_JJhDn8PkV9w-aM_ww.review_text: Ok so this would be more of a 4.5/5 stars, but yelp doesn't allow for it. This restaurant has been here for as long as I can remember. We used to come here every year. It was our go to place to bring family from out of town and it never failed to impress. If you want to eat at a decent time, make a reservation!! The wait on any given day can be 30 min to 2 hours.   If and when you do come you ABSOLUTELY MUST get the clam chowder because it is quite honestly the BEST I've ever had here in CA. The lobster bisque is also to die for (if I were any less civilized I would have licked the bowl). Their grilled scallops were amazing, fresh, and cooked to perfection. Personally I'm a sucker for cioppino and the one here is super tasty and loaded with seafood. Fish here is cooked perfectly - flaky and fresh (can't really go wrong with any fish you order). The seafood pastas here are enough to feed 2 comfortably and they are def not stingy on the seafood. Another must get is the calamari (they have spicy or regular) - so GOOD!! Perfectly crispy/seasoned on the outside and tender on the inside.    Cons:  - Possible long wait times for tables  - On the pricey side (BUT totally worth the splurge - trust me!)  Pros: - Giant portion sizes  - Seafood is very fresh - Great atmosphere (slightly old fashioned, but classy) - Service is always top notch  - Free valet parking

gfnPfaedHcM5lFntUnFAxg.review_text: Yes, it's pricey but it's also on the wharf. The wharf is teeming with tourists, but Scomas has been an SF classic so you'll find a mix of both locals and tourists here. I recently came here for the "SF Dine About Town" event.   Clam chowder (4/5): good, not too salty, fresh Pasta Girabaldi (4/5): very fresh seafood; pasta sauce could have used more salt   Overall, I had a pleasant dining experience. I'll be back again.
