b6armaswyJDiEYZKQHnYsg.review_text: This was absolutely marvelous! Worth of waiting for 40 minutes in the bar, worth of waiting 40 minutes of cooking! Our 1/2 spicy garlic crab and mix of sea-creatures was absolutely awesome! 5 star!   Ah, waiters! Worth of extra twenty :) great guys!

ttauTXuRemnMf1SDhMgQZQ.review_text: Overrated.  Long wait.   Food is not worth it. I had the prixie fixie. I felt like my lobster bisque was a tomato basil soup. As for my main entree, I had the pasta with scallops. I love scallops but this reminds me of a pasta dish that olive garden can make. I wasn't impressed, it was very bland.   As for my dessert, I didn't care for it.  Everyone gets served bread with butter.   I felt like I waited long for mediocre food. Everything on yelp loves this place but the seafood didn't blow me away. It reminds me of a food from a chain restaurant. Parking can be difficult here. There's valet parking as an option though.

53bZ_EsXH71L7iFs5MP9_w.review_text: The drive down the Embaradero was excruciating.  Took 20 minutes to get down 1 mile of road, we finally turned on a side street and followed the parallel road.    So happy to find FREE valet in one of the most crowded areas in the city.    Our party of four was told the wait was going to be about 20 minutes, but it ended up being about 45 minutes, it was 5pm on a Saturday.    I can understand why it would be painful waiting outside in the cold, but really grab a stool and just order a cocktail.  It made EVERYTHING rosy.  The bartenders are quite warm.    Scoma's doesn't do revolutionary food, but well executed fresh seafood.  Take advantage of the $35 tasting menu, a special menu offered after 5pm, appetizer, entree and dessert, there is a pretty good selection.  One in our party ordered, while the rest of us ordered ala carte.  Very flexible.    Flowing freebies: water was a plenty and the bread was always filled.  Kind of old school with the refrigerated butter wrapped in foil, but the EVOO was a welcome relief.    The cioppino was gargantuan, I was kind of put off by the $37 pricetag, when it came to the table, it definitely changed my mind, I can make 4 meals out of the bowl.  So many fresh ingredients and bucketloads of it.  I'm used to a dainty portion.  What I would have liked more of was the toasted garlic bread.  Soaking it in the tomato based broth was heavenly.  The filet was served with sides, hearty portions and a great sear.  The desserts were good, I especially enjoyed my tiramisu, fluffy and strong espresso flavor.      It was a fun meal hosting out of town guests, but I wouldn't put myself through the ringer to eat here on a regular basis.

5cUVYZlmUCwqlOxBVP15Lw.review_text: Scoma's was amazing.  My girlfriend was dying to bring me here, so when we went I had high expectations.   They were all met.  The ambiance is classic 70s wharf, and the history is palpable.  I believe some of the wait staff may be early generation employees.    The food is phenomenal.  I still dream of the swordfish my girlfriend ordered.  Everything was seasoned perfectly, and the portions are on the heavier side of hearty.  Both of us were up later that night scarfing down on our leftovers.

BUeueHeX3mzlyEBEEK9quQ.review_text: Father's Day 2014...  My wife and daughters brought me to Scoma's Restaurant because they thought I am the coolest Dad in the world, beating the likes of Cliff Huxtable, Tim Taylor, and Al Bundy.  I know they are just being kind because that distinction belongs to the one and only Homer Jay Simpson.  I probably am a distant second, but I don't mind taking a backseat to one S-M-R-T man.  For our dinner, we ordered a bowl of Scoma's Famous Clam Chowder, Calamari Fritti, the Prix Fixe Dinner, and the much heralded Lazy Man's Cioppino.  Scoma's Famous Clam Chowder is one of the better clam chowders not served in a sourdough bread.  It is the creamy kind with plenty of chopped up clams.  The Calamari Fritti was tender with a well-seasoned and crusty exterior.  The Prix Fixe Dinner consisted of Lobster Bisque with Lobster Salad and Chive Aioli as the appetizer, Calico Scallops and Fettuccini as the entrée, and Chocolate Brownie with Vanilla Bean Ice Cream as the dessert.  The appetizer was good but very minimal.  My daughter seemed to enjoy the entrée which had sun-dried tomato and cream.  Everybody shared the dessert in a hurry to prevent the warm brownie from melting the ice cream.  The contrast in temperature made this so enjoyable.  Saving the best for the last, I have to give them props for their Lazy Man's Cioppino.  From the freshness of the ingredients to the taste of the broth, this has been the best of all the cioppinos we have tried.  This is a notch above my favorite at Woodhouse Fish Co. and I will pick this over Sotto Mare's self-proclaimed "Best Damn Crab Cioppino" any day.  Cioppino's at Jefferson St. has their lazy man's version as well but it is definitely not in the same class.  I have also recently tried the cioppino at Sam's Chowder House at Half Moon Bay, Vivolo's Chowder House at Pacific Grove, and Brophy Brothers at Santa Barbara and none of them came close.  I have yet to try Tadich Grill, Anchor Oyster Bar, or Crab House at Pier 39 so I will have to update this  when I get the chance to try theirs.  Dining at Scoma's can be costly but it is well worth the price especially when celebrating a special occasion.  This is worthy of a 5-star rating but I had to take away a star because they have that "controversial" 4% surcharge that some of the San Francisco restaurants collect supposedly for the health and welfare of their staff.  I think we have paid more than enough for the food, the tax, the tip, and even the to-go container that we don't want to see anymore surcharges on our bill.  Other than that, everything else went very well...

TaymD7MKm8OH1VI77kMWMw.review_text: An old but still solid establishment on the wharf. My dad still reminisces about this place when he is back in SF so naturally we came here during father's day weekend for dinner. First just know that if you decide to come here, be prepared to wait. There's no way around it. They don't take reservations, so just get your name on the list and grab a few drinks at the bar or walk around while you wait. They overestimated our wait time, lucky for us, but it was still about an hour around 8 or 9pm on a Friday.   Our waiter, Sal, was great. He must also be an old-timer because we noticed more regular customers chatting him up, and he was great in pacing our meal really well, providing helpful recommendations for food, and all around just making sure we were having a good time.   Food... Yeah seafood is the way to go. I have no comments on the red meat here because frankly I don't see why you'd want that at a seafood place on the pier. The chowder is pretty tasty, and it's more creamy than it is full of large seafood bits. The warm appetizer trio had good calamari and crab cakes. The shrimp was fine too but not super amazing. The swordfish fagioli is a solid dish - also has some pancetta and leafy greens. I loved my seafood mix sauté plate, which was not only HUGE but very tasty, tons of large crabmeat pieces, 2 1/2 lobster tails, about 4 large scallops and at least 2 or 3 shrimp on top of a bed of rice + pasta (not sure why there was both) plus lots of veggies. I could only finish about 1/2. Seared tuna is also a good choice.   Overall, a great dining experience. The wait was long, but worth a good time had by all.

PVyMWt-NpDJF41NAkdIPiQ.review_text: Just OK.   Went here on my first trip to SF and expected the best.seafood.ever. considering the whole Fisherman's Wharf thing. Oysters were good (they were raw - not much to say to the chef there), clam chowder was in desperate need of salt and pepper, and lobster tail was also good (again, that kind of speaks for itself).  The restaurant was crazy busy, tables too close together, and atmosphere was just meh.   Very upsetting, yelpers. First time you've disappointed me.

FVkLfQhvng1NNRW4V6YHGA.review_text: Very busy but accommodating at the same time. Great seafood & thoroughly enjoyed my dinner.  Cocktails left a bit to be desired.  Tried 3 different ones but none were up to snuff. Caesar salad was very light with a fantastic dressing which is not the ordinary for a caesar salad.

C4OkiPljZ3z2XUa7onmihQ.review_text: This place is always good.  Had the halibut broiled and it was freakin unbelievable.  It's like getting a filet that's perfectly between medium rare and medium.  Fantastic.  The swordfish piccata was outstanding as well.  The frank family cab was very good.  I would just say that they should spill a little more in the glass.  The spumoni was very good and little espresso to boot.  Just a consistent place.  Go there.

9lAicAw7kzNqaumpKoh-VA.review_text: We were excited by all the seafood options and so went a little overboard.  We started with the Hot appetizer for two. Delicious shrimp, yummy calamari, but the highlight was by far the crab cakes.  Yummy!  I had the Scallops and prawns. So good. Beautifully sautéed and firm but not rubbery or stringy. Just pure scallopy goodness!  My boyfriend had a lightly breaded fish, which I thought was delicious, but breaded fish wasn't really his thing... so ask because the menu doesn't give a lot of details.  Scoma's is old-school.  Decor is all wood-panelling and the servers are uniformed with those old-fashioned jackets.  Maybe it could use a bit of a facelift but it was a lovely romantic dinner for two!

_owMBYfzT9dO7FXGXXzXqA.review_text: Scoma's may have been known for seafood, views, and service in 1965, but it's been completely outdone by a plethora of restaurants in SF since then. My girl friends and I came for Dine About Town a few days ago because $35.95 for a three-course dinner seemed like a steal in light of entrees costing that much alone here.   I chose the dungeness crab cakes, the lamb T-bones with parmesan polenta, and the pumpkin cheesecake. Nothing was bad, but everything was bland. For example, the crab cakes could have benefited from a curry or garlic aioli; the lamb would have been tastier with a balsamic vinegar glaze; the cheesecake should have had a thicker graham cracker crust. Dinner didn't appear to be a deal after I tasted the food.  I was also peeved that the host promised us a 40-minute wait (Scoma's doesn't take reservations), which actually turned into a 1-hour 10-minute wait. It's always better to estimate liberally. If I knew we had to wait that long, I would've just dined at another restaurant.   The view IS easy on the eyes, though.    Scoma's is yet another old, semi-stuffy restaurant that makes you wonder how it's still surviving and thriving in a city with over 4,500 restaurants, many of them serving delicious food at reasonable prices. How many licks does it take to get to the center of a tootsie pop? Nobody knows.

D2epirooWNjvwTI6MFhNGw.review_text: I have a confession. I was born and raised in San Francisco. Still live in San Francisco. I've never been to Alcatraz.  You know what else?  I didn't eat at Scoma's until this year.  SHAME ON ME.   First thing to note: great service. Waiters are super cool and chill yet professional.  Great view of the water and the docks.   They have a pre fix lunch for I think it was $25 but oh lord somebody really should have warned me that it is a MASSIVE amount of food that you get! My friend ordered an appetizer sampler from the regular menu. i tried not to eat too much since we both had the pre fix.  For my pre fix meal I had  clam chowder - heaping amounts of clams in it, definitely fresh. tasty.   pasta - I forgot what exactly it was called but it was linguini with fresh mussels and salmon. Boy they do not skimp on the amount of seafood they give you! Really really tasty but I was barely able to finish half.   chocolate cake - too rich for me and I just don't like chocolate (I know, I know. What girl DOESN'T like chocolate!?!? Yea yea, well THIS ONE does not like chocolate so live with it)  My friend had the salad that had a mountain of crab meat and shrimp on it. That seems to be one of the most popular items ordered there because I kept seeing plate after plate of that being served up.   I'd definitely come back for some crab.

pJEOLjW9O99SLISSFRueHg.review_text: We were very very disappointed in our recent meal at Scoma. We have eaten there before and it was average, but this time is was just poor. The crab risotto was very very tasteless, full of chewy slimy mushrooms and slight on the crab. My wife got the fish of the day and very underwhelming overall for the cost.   We have eaten at much better places for much less and there are certainly options in San Fran that I would suggest you consider.  This unfortunately was just an awful meal and the chatter from the table next to us was similar. Look elsewhere.

lB5ZDDVEhXzMdbRte_xZ8w.review_text: Went for our friends anniversary. Was a wonderful experience. The parking is a little tricky and the wait can be long but well worth it. Our server has been there for like 25years, he was entertaining and attentive.  My friend had the Chipino and her husband had fish. Both raved how delightful their meals were.  My husband and I had Filet Mignon. Cooked perfectly, flavorful and juicy. We wanted to stay and continue to sit our wine and chat away the evening.  The seating is tight so if you want something intimate this really is not the place but wonderful atmosphere, service and food.

me3msnteOfLhtroz02Zfbw.review_text: A friend recommended this for happy hour: great deals in bar and lounge with $5 appetizers 4:30-6:00 Monday-Friday. The crab cakes were wonderful, capped off with a bit of a delectable Caesar garnishment. We also had the fried oysters and torpedo shrimp. Definitely worth a return visit.

BQIISvsItoqclDOFOnQlsw.review_text: When visiting San Francisco, they say you gotta have cioppino.  And considering mixed shellfish in a tomato broth is one of the best dishes ever invented, it wasn't long before I was asking where one of the best places to get it might be when visiting the Bay area.  Enter Scoma's.  I'm sure they have a lot of outstanding seafood here, including Dungeness crab, but this place is all about the Lazy Man's Cioppino.  Cod, scallops, clams, shrimp, crab, mussels.  It's all here in a tomato based broth. THIS is the best stew I've ever had in any form.  They serve it with a big wedge of San Francisco sour dough for dipping but, if you're lucky, as I was, your waiter might just bring you a little side of pasta on the house to further soak up all that broth.  After all, those of us here in the east are used to melding our fish based stews with tomato sauce and pasta!  It's the ideal way to go!  Scoma's also has a 1970's based decor because it looks like they've never updated anything since then.  That's OK.  I love 70's style chic.  But you're not here to be comforted by the decor.  The Lazy Man's cioppino will do that for you and do it very well.

t1BFxagTLj_NRFd8_nn7pw.review_text: Ate dinner at Scoma's tonight with my new Husband - we are on our honeymoon in San Francisco.  The tour bus driver highly recommended Scoma's as the best seafood restaurant in the area.  When we walked over I was a bit skeptical.  I'm so glad I stayed.  The food was outstanding and our waiter, John, had worked there for over 20 years - he was absolutely the best.  We had a remarkable meal and a memorable date night out.  Thank you John and Scoma's for a great memory.  We will definitely be back!

VEgMc0Jat_HMTrnQ3ZWnEw.review_text: On a trip to San Fran we asked our hotel a good place to get seafood and they recommended Scoma's.  I was really excited when we got to the location and let down soon after.  I ordered the lobster ravioli $30.  The ravioli was overcooked and I could barely taste the lobster.  Between the prices and the taste I was disappointed.  Definitely to much $$ for the quality.

xvIk2MWmxZhXhgJzqx6shQ.review_text: Ate at several restaurants while in SF this weekend, very disappointed until dining at Scomas!  Totally the "wow" we have been waiting for! From seating, to bus staff, wait staff to end of meal. WOW! Meal was excellent, service was  great and meal was awesome!  Totally recommend Scoma's!  John B was the BOMB!

P4b9u28jXzigsPGrT-W0xw.review_text: This place is off the beaten path, but worth it.  Unfortunately, many has found this place and there is about an hour wait.  Cioppino and Clam Chowder was delicious!  I would definitely recommend.

q3I9eS1_Smr5-zGFeLff6g.review_text: We all had a good time . The food was good and filling.  The clam chowder was delicious as was the clams on the half shell.  The steamed lobster was ok. The Shrimp Louis was good and they served my wife's allergy need for no gluten and no dairy well.  I'm ready for the next Bay Area trip.

JgzsbQFK07qkCMM9yvribQ.review_text: We loved this cozy restaurant. We were seated quickly but our waiter was able to get us a table by the window. The scallops were excellent and the menu had too many choices based on all of the wonderful entrées we saw around us. Can't wait to give it a try next time we are on the wharf.

h8ojg0Tj_pbljI44GFTnwQ.review_text: Scoma's is always my "go-to" place for out of town guests who need to experience a real San Francisco treat.  Made last minute reservations for Saturday night and they couldn't have been more helpful or accommodating.  We waited a bit, but had a terrific table.  The food and service were fantastic as always and my guests were delighted.  I cannot recommend this San Francisco tradition more highly!!!!

b_Uiy1m7QNoDpzB8MnpHOg.review_text: The Cioppino was really flavorful and had a ton of seafood in it. You could probably get one to share. It is really filling and comes with a side of bread you can dip in the sauce.   The drinks were strong and yummy. I had the peartini and the golden gate sunrise.   The wait staff was incredibly friendly. It had a lively and fun atmosphere and the restaurant is right on the water front. I would visit again even though it was a bit pricy.

ZS1SinwKRtKp59QFPUDB_g.review_text: This is an awesome old school seafood restaurant in San Francisco. its out on the wharf and they dont take reservations.   The lobster Thermidor is the best and i have tried it in several other countries and no one comes close to making it better.  A great place to take someone special! Service is prompt and always professional with a smile.

UGGpN4-q_4cf3SZ3mBJdbg.review_text: I dined on the prix fixe dinner menu which was a great value at $44. My starter was the lobster bisque which was creamy with just the right amount of spice to make it pop with flavor. It was served with a small tasting of lobster salad. The seared tuna for my entree was perfectly prepared with a side of vegetables. Dessert was a perfect ending with a chocolate brownie which arrived with whipped cream, ice cream and caramel topping. The service was efficient and friendly, and my overall experience was very good.

4ALOxfvxnnWyun5B9Txmww.review_text: Scoma's is one of our special occasion restaurants. Ordered my favorite seafood Louie salad today and was a little disappointed to see it stashed for ten minutes in the busser's station while waiting for my husband's order to come out. All those dirty dishes piled next to my salad was a little unappetizing.

P2xv-jXk22flUgLBtfGMSQ.review_text: Great place to eat if you have a large budget. Very fancy with lots of stars photos on the wall. We only had appetizers and they were excellent. Not really kid friendly. Make a reservation or you'll be waiting.

h1BV6ILuNK7vfatxhbm8aQ.review_text: The salad and dessert were great as was the service. However, the lobster was over cooked and thus a bit tough and lacked flavor.

eWLfQTpl53Tuo7_BSMlT2Q.review_text: We went on a recommendation from a friend who, incidentally, left us a gift certificate there. My first impression was relief at the fact that the restaurant sits far back from the craziness that is fisherman's wharf. We were promptly seated at a window table. The service was top-notch; our water glasses were always full. The martinis were excellent and the food was even better.  Loved it.

3MeZ2Zl7t0zrhRaVJx75-g.review_text: Its really hard to say something that hasn't already been said before.  Some of the highlights that I noticed; 1.) The parking is great, the valet takes care of everything, and there is no charge in the parking meter infested city.  2.) The lines are usually long, this is a very busy and successful restaurant make sure to make the reservation, don't drop in.  3.) Recommendation that should be your last meal on earth; Pasta Pomodoro with PRAWNS, its about 31.00 but I comment on the following;  a.) the prawns are huge, fresh, and plenty b.) the noodles and mix of cheese and pesto is amazing c.) The sauce is to die for, what you find yourself doing is searching for bread on the table to clean up every last drop of the amazing, attractive, red tomato Poodoro sauce.  You will look like a drug phene completely high on Tomato Sauce.  Go try Scomas, Live Big for the weekend.  Your date will probably want ot get married

XxTf-dF1lfOBgLGV-mbyfg.review_text: Gonna throw two stars (2.5) with the hope that its noted.  Forever & a day our crew has been coming to Scoma's.  The typical order? Cioppino "lazy."  Apparently, (but, I don't know,) Chef Scarbosio has left the building, and that may be the reason.  The presentation, flavor, and entire dish was just off, Way off.  #disappointed.

Py4uSNauadyXKMxMm2Ty-w.review_text: Boyfriend treated me to a romantic dinner here and omg what an amazing chef they have! Worth every cent and more! Not only was the ambiance nice but looking out into the water from our table was beautiful! Had the lobster ravioli and omg, each ravioli was like heaven. The taste was so rich that I still remember it perfectly. It might be pricey but so worth it! The food in volume was not filling but in taste filled me for a while. I thoroughly enjoyed our meal and bottle of wine, my boyfriend who tends to be very stoic about everything was actually very impressed. I'm hella picky and really don't like spending tons of money on mediocre food. So this place definitely came through and more.

eC3_iAlNzRMh4mY4eut94A.review_text: I brought my wife here on Sunday for lunch. I expected she would really enjoy but, the French waiter was totally overbearing. He kept telling us we should not order so much. He should leave that to the customer so we could have tried many things. The price was never a concern, only great food. He really killed the fun for us!!

ZH2BsTXtOrzgNLFGDFsogA.review_text: I have been to Scoma's multiple times, with a large group, with a small group, and alone.  I really like this place.  To me, it best captures the spirit of good seafood in San Francisco.  The restaurant is situated on the end of a pier on Fisherman's Wharf.  You can drive out to the end, and they will valet park your car.  The motif is classic, nostalgic, withe celebrity photos.  The menus contains a great selection of fresh seafood items.  There are great appetizers, salads and entrees.  I literally have never had anything bad here.  Service is great.  I can hear Tony Bennett singing "I Left My Heart in San Francisco" in the background.  I recommend this place to all my friends who are visiting San Francisco.

mD8T6tegVU9v06osh8W2sA.review_text: I wouldn't say the views are all that rad since the break wall is right in front of the location but they aren't too shabby.  We popped in for a beer which was priced cheaper than expected and the bartenders were very nice and hospitable.   We checked out the menu and the pricing is about the average rate for higher end seafood restaurants.   I'd like to come back in for some grub.  And if you are interested they do valet parking in the back.

2J4SwmI7UczrgZTmm-mpvA.review_text: After a disappointing Forty Niners lost, we had an amazing birthday dinner at Scoma's. The bartenders and wait staff are always first right and the food as wonderful. Scoma's is a San Francisco institution for a reason. For me, they are top of my list, second only to The House of Prime Rib. The food was cooked to perfection and the wait staff, not only responded to our requests, they anticipated them. A meal at Scoma's is a must anytime you visit the City by the Bay.

RQj4Lf2yfWyUaOgn8FhuDQ.review_text: alwyz LUVD scomas. used to come here all the time when i lived in sf. came back on a visit to sf over the weekend and ordered their famous cioppino to go (thats all i ever order frm here). before, when id order it to go, theyd make it the same way as if id ordered it when dining in. but this time? SOOO DISAPPOINTED! totally gypped me! there wuz nth in there except for a lil bit of seafood and tomato paste! and the portion? wayyy smaller! had to come home and add my own vegetables and more seafood and recooked it. SUGGESTION: DONT ORDER TO GO! total rip-off! trust me. paid $40 for a lousy cioppino that i had to re-make myself anywyz!

ZxvaErjVi8OKu_fxR_a-3A.review_text: Good food, all seafood is very fresh, reasonable price, impressive service, Lillian is the best server, She is very helpful and sweet.

QZNLJ68kuS51Tlqljvf3ow.review_text: It is off the beaten path, but it's worth the walk off the main drag.  The food is excellent and the service is solid.  Old school and a family favorite for many years.

17e5W0HaRJ2kgQApt_5wHw.review_text: The steamed clams were amazing, and the clam chowder was delicious. There is balance in their dishes. The ingredients are simple and straightforward (garlic, onions, clams), but the execution and taste in your mouth is to die for. Better seafood here than anywhere else in the city, including Crustaceans.

iZ4kRJm0ghqZJ5w2EPY4KQ.review_text: Great calamari! Some of the best I have had and I don't eat seafood! Artichoke and spinach salad were great too

TZelLnaGbHgaG7LBI6rfgg.review_text: This place is tucked away behind the main strip and a classic seafood spot in the area. Very old school and the decor matches. Do not expect a modern seafood take. It's meant for the tourists and the elder sf crowd.  If you want to take the grandparents out, then this place might be the right pace but don't expect any innovative or flashy items. Overall, not the vibe and style of food I enjoy. The price point is high and an update would be helpful both in decor and on the menu.

fLwVV89u4chh2mQ8eaTAIw.review_text: I had to get Dungeness crab before returning from a trip to San Francisco, and I had to dine with my suitcase to do so. I wasn't disappointed. I first had the scrumptious bisque, and the crab was nothing short of amazing.  I might have been willing to be clawed by Oscar (my name for my crustacean) to taste his delectable pinchers, though that would have made it difficult to crack the shell. I was willing to sacrifice my cholesterol reading to dip my legs (rather, his) into the melted butter.  Very old-school waiter in dress and manner provided exquisite service, especially for such a casual place. And I thought the place would be over-run by tourists. Certainly the majority were, but not the "overrunning types." This might be because the place is a block toward the bay from Beach Street. I only found it through Yelp. Great public transportation nearby, including the classic, antique streetcars that go to the Ferry Building.  Beautiful location, on a dock right on the bay, with what look like fishing boats on the dock (not many of these left on the piers anymore). A perfect, final meal before I left the city.

8g7IvR1ZGPaRRS9i_U_4sw.review_text: This place was amazing! The salmon was super fresh and prepared perfectly. My husband had the lobster tail. It was huge and so tasty. The service was great. It was the best meal I have ever had in San Fran.

pUV7yun5ZEM9DCA_P2lj5Q.review_text: DISAPPOINTING.  After having Scoma's a couple of years ago I HAD to come back here as soon as I was financially capable of doing so. lol. I came here expecting a delicious meal and unfortunately didn't get that. I had a pretty inadequate waiter.   Me & my boyfriend Ordered: Oyster Rockefeller Calamari 2 Filet Mignons  Our water took our order, didn't ask how we wanted our meat cooked, and left before we could catch him. By the time we caught him he said the order had already been put in, so we just had to stick with it.  Our filet mignons came out and they were completely flavorless, dry, and overcooked. I was beyond sad that the place that I've been looking forward to eating at was such a huge let down..

YM6Z2255UgCwKKskfIrP_A.review_text: Seafood so fresh they hire boat captains to fish for them and they even have a processing area across from the restaurant. Ordered their market grilled fish and it was simply the best I EVER had in SF. Also ordered their calimari, crab cakes, and shrimp that were just rich. Also tried their lobster bisque which was the BEST I ever had. I appreciate the staff ( an ARMY of them) and guests ratio. It is pricey but u get the very real "fresh" seafood from the ocean to the fork food.

jq8zJR-Ew8QKjGudPmL8IQ.review_text: The hubs, our 11 month old, and I went here for our anniversary dinner. Best fish I've ever had! Cooked to perfection! I ordered the fish trio. My husband had a seafood pasta and we shared the stuffed portobello mushroom. I was a little nervous coming to a nice restaurant with a baby, but the waiter was so good with her. The restaurant was very family friendly. We will definitely be back next time we are in San Fran!!

cKci42jLfslgS2ptCpm-bw.review_text: Not like it used to be....we used to love coming here when I lived in the city.  The food was fresh, tasty, and the atmosphere was buzzing.  Now, the wait was just as long, food bland, and the service was suffering.  After waiting an hour for a table "by a window" so our daughter could see the water during dinner, we were seated away from the windows completely.  Our server mentioned that it took her 15-20 min to take our order because she told us 6 tables were seated in her section at the same time, she didn't apologize for the wait, and continued to do the blame game until there was an awkward silence.  (I wanted to leave then but we were already an hour and a half into this)   We were literally not even acknowledged and thank God another employee noticed our wait and brought us bread while we were waiting.  (strike 2) and then the worst...we waited so long to be seated, waited on, and then our food...and the food was blah!!! I ordered the organic chicken and pasta, and the chicken was so difficult to eat because it was over cooked the skin could break a window.  The calamari had no flavor, and our salad had so much dressing on it that it made the lettuce soggy.  I am sad because this had always been my go to restaurant a while back, but it looks like things have changed a lot.  There are so many options.  I would venture and try another place for the wait, quality of food, and the kind of service you will get.

lQXbo83bGxE7l6SOT_CpVQ.review_text: meh  The Looks: Dated The Cost: Pricy The Service: Prompt, but far from stellar. The Food Quality: That was fresh caught?? The Location: Very Good  Well, I stopped in on a night with a coworker and we ordered the calamari, lobster ravioli, and burger.  Lobster ravioli was so so, nothing special.  Calamari was a bit on the chewy side, how is this, i dunno...  Burger was surprisingly the best thing on the table, even though it was basically a single patty big mac. Same type of bun, lettuce, special sauce. The beef was actually pretty good. A shame they didn't spring for better bread.  Will I return, not likely.

8TQ4QWrbS6nKvQAjvQMbug.review_text: Don't be taken in by the other places at Fisherman's Wharf, and for heaven's sake don't go to Joe's Crab Shack.  This place was pricey but delicious.  I arrived for lunch alone and in very casual clothing, but was treated kindly and given the same excellent service as the people who were dressed up.   It seems to be a place where employees  come and stay for a long time. I had great conversations with both the Valet Manager and the server (Sean).  I didn't want the lobster bisque to end...and I did find some lobster in there (sorry, other Yelper).  The prawn cocktail was fresh and it was a generous portion (although it was 17 bucks).  The garlic dungeness crab was delicious as well. Sean tied my bib on for me and gave me a quick refresher tutorial on how to use the crab tools.  After I was through, I was given lemon wedges and a hot towel (eating that crab was a little messy).     I do not believe they take reservations, although the full menu is served all day.  The Valet Manager advised me that it gets VERY busy during the dinner rush.  Have a big lunch or an early dinner and make this place your splurge meal in SF

cFXEfwiQgWhaTBZ_CaaZ_w.review_text: We were walking around Pier 39 and decided to go here with our little girl for lunch.  They were great with our 2 year old.  The food was pretty good but very pricey for lunch (what else would you expect at Pier 39).  Clam chowder was above average, crab cakes as well.  The petrale dole was good but would have been better with some tartar sauce.  My wife had the pasta that came with the pre fixed lunch menu and she liked it.  Only down side was that our server forgot to bring out my sprite and instead of serving my fish with mashed potatoes like I asked for, it came with penne.  She did try to make up for it by not charging for the sprite and a side of mashed for free which was appreciated, but she still did forget two of my items.  I do think it was just a bad day for her and would not hold it against the restaurant.  We would go back for a special occasion

gzU54aTUyrBmHAseiCfuKA.review_text: For the money I was very unimpressed.  I was expecting warm bread not cold, SOME kind of seasoning for the Alfredo pasta with scallops, and a delicious $12 Cesar salad not lettuce & croutons with a side of oil.  Won't go back unfortunately :(

Eva274V0UhvqY4owmBEu9w.review_text: Okay, if a friend or relative comes into town and says they want to spend the day in San Francisco as a tourist, the next thing out of their mouths is usually Fisherman's Wharf.  Being a native California girl, I grew up with my Dad taking us to FW every time anyone new would come to town.  We'd wander the streets in search of that perfect bowl of chowder and some fresh crab.  Now it's my turn to play host and secretly I'm excited anytime I get this opportunity.  It brings back all of those childhood memories and let's me eat some really terrific food.  But now that the pocketbook is a bit bigger, instead of just browsing the chowder vendors, we make a special lunch trip to Scomas for some truly fantastic food and great service.  They have lunch specials that are under $20 that Hubby and Sis tried.  Sis had the Crab and Shrimp Louie and said she had never seen a Louie with so much seafood on it.  Piles of fresh shellfish that was stunningly delicious.  Hubby had the Fish & Chips, but wasn't crazy about them.  I had the Salmon and Shrimp Alfredo which had a light and lovely sauce that wasn't too heavy and really hit the spot.  Delicious!  The wine list is packed full of fabulous wine to go along with everyone's meal and we enjoyed a fine bottle of red.  So the next time a friend comes to town and asks to play tourist at Fisherman's Wharf, don't cringe - indulge!!  Scoma's is the way to recharge your energy before wandering the streets of San Francisco.

yR-6YxGdgNJTBfJtQ5CmRw.review_text: Ahhh another SF great spot. I've been coming here since I was little kid. Totally touristy for the most part but it reminds me of old San Francisco. I like to play tourist once and a while and come to the Warf. The dishes come with big portions of whatever you get. I usually get the halibut or sea food pasta and it is always so good. Yes its full of butter goodness but its OK to eat like that once in a while.. DON'T JUDGE ME! :-)   The service is almost always great and the waiters are so nice and cheerful. Tourist or not this is a great place to get some food and enjoy San Francisco.

vAkpKtEvDxxavhva_vAIxw.review_text: This place was recommended by a friend, so we tracked it down on the pier. The food was incredible. We had a simple lunch, which included the clam chowder and the butternut squash soup. We nearly lucked our bowls! The sourdough bread was delish, especially with the chowder. The hostess was prompt in seating us and polite. I liked the sports memorabilia in the decor. The family running this place clearly has their act together. Thank you for great food and service!

PWaLh-C6KzdYZEzXm79rzw.review_text: can't get any fresher than the oyster bar. although right in the middle of manhattan, you'll feel like you're in a cape cod diner (that's a good thing!).

_97mETTo80KxClh1sOV36Q.review_text: I have returned to Scoma's again and once again I was very happy. I felt that an additional review was in order and to encourage Scoma's to keep doing what they do. One of the most pleasant experiences is having good food and consistent food each time you eat at one of your fav restaurants. Thanks once again.  Don't hesitate to give Scoma's a try. The prices are about consistent with other restaurants in the area but I do feel the food is top notch here. I wish I could eat here more often but grateful each time that I can.   I believe if you make the right choice on food that you will be happy with your experience at Scoma's. I'm not the only one that raves about Scoma's as is evident by AAA, TripAdvisor, Local Tour Guide Brochures, and even Yelp. Bravo Scoma's.

mVVKTOLK1qt0hxNNh_UCIg.review_text: First of all,I love Scoma's. I have been eating here for close to 20 years, and the food has always been excellent. However on my most recent visit I was disappointed to learn that they had replaced their excellent rice pilaf with a chewy risotto and rice mix that  has very little flavor. They have also gotten rid of the vegetable mix of broccoli, cauliflower, and carrots! These accompanied one of my favorite entrees, the prawns and scallops alla Gannon which I will no longer order until they return to serving it with the rice pilaf and vegetable mix.

jvIbrfeXHz7tGpONEr3mcA.review_text: I have been going to Scomas for approximately 20 years now at the rate of two or three times a year......   I can't say that I've tried alot of dishes there as I am (or was) a lover of their Lazyman Chiapiono.    We went last Friday and I ordered the same thing....   This fish stew in the past has been wonderful...   What I got on Friday for $40 was tomato sauce with COD.....  I had two small pcs of Crab, Two Shrimp and two clams.....  The rest was tastless cod....   I was very disappointed and will now return to this establishment....

E-Mq9XSHtu4n85SXlV-AAA.review_text: The reason I give this place 5 stars even though my lunch was more of a 4 star quality is because of the amazing service that we got at this place. After a morning of playing tourist, my fiance and I wanted to stop to get some lunch. We were at the Wharf so we were obviously craving clam chowder but wanted an actual sit down place.  Upon walking in, I noticed the servers with the white jackets and immediately thought that this would be hoighty toighty place that would judge me for just ordering a beer and bowl of chowder. However, this did not happen. Our waiter was super friendly and made some small talk with us. The busboys made sure we had plenty of water and we generally felt very welcome here.   As far as the m... my Stella was ice cold and my chowder was delicious so I was a happy girl. I really liked that my chowder was heavy on the clams and lighter on the potatoes. We also got half of a giant roll of sourdough bread in our bread basket so that was perfect for dipping... no breadbowl needed here. I was also intrigued by some of their other seafood chowders which I will have to try if I make my way to Scoma's again. eal

FjoX_MlzeWijmwkpfjFCSw.review_text: Haven't had a lot of fresh seafood in such a while so my wife and I indulged in shrimp cocktail and fresh calamari (best calamari ever!), we shared Halibut and the Salmon over lobster raviolli. Both were great but the Halobut here rocks!

MF7q-2IBUnqfMmixmcP6dg.review_text: Excellent food I highly recommend  The crab cakes are delicious and the service is spectacular. Our waiter Kevin was pleasant and knowledgeable and made our meal complete. We will be back

nW8ujzozMdCPeEhD-_QRcA.review_text: I've been to scomas many times and it is excellent every time. The service for this past visit was personable and fast. I loved the sole (fish dore), the recommendation of our waiter. It was a huge portion size but very delicious. Scomas may be a little touristy but it's well worth it!

ZuExuTpG8PMhwi7mH6vbTg.review_text: If you want seafood while you're in SF, this place is pretty much off the hook.  You an dress up and valet park or you can wander in wearing jeans, not matter what you'll eat amazing food.  Oysters Rockefeller, Shrimp AND Crab Louie....or pasta and steak.   The service is amazing as well as the view.  Give it a shot!

83zq60Wt8HDr9Lh1gIOWSA.review_text: I have a simple view on Fisherman's Wharf - if you must eat here, then you must go to Scoma's. I've gone to Scoma's for years, and you can bank on very fresh seafood in a comfortable yet a bit old school establishment. And that's a good thing - just flashy enough to dress up a bit if you like but still comfortable if you've been out doing the tourist thing and need a great late lunch break. On the last visit I had sand dabs, and they were absolutely perfect, the light sweetness of the fish offset with the lemon and capers. A crisp California white wine and some great sourdough bread just made it a perfect and simple meal.  Oh, and if you wonder what other locations I recommend in the Wharf area, it's easy - I don't.

z26-1gC14g4fe5wqbn4rJw.review_text: The only drawback of this restaurant is its location, besides that, everything about this place is wonderful.  The staff is defiantly above average, and the food is amazing.  They serve excellent crab cakes, not a lot of breading.

K7W2UaUGJvpbqiqObRhQQQ.review_text: Outstanding!  Wonderful service and tremendous food.  I had the oysters to start, then the garlic roasted crab with a side of spinach - everything was tremendous.  The freshest crab and that spinach!  Who knew?  My husband had fisherman's pasta and was nice enough to let me try it - I could see why he was hesitant - it was too good to share!  All around great place.

NRrNQ5xHn_7Fu4ctlpKLbQ.review_text: I nominate Scoma's as the flagship classic seafood restaurant for San Francisco. All seafood restaurants will be compared to this gem from this day forward. Go here now. The portions are huge and preparation perfect.  Service was excellent and the food was unparalleled.   Me - Crab cakes with sauce - 5 stars. These were the best Crab cakes I've had in recent memory. Girlfriend - Fish soup "It's like a little aquarium in my bowl." Drinks are OK.  Valet parking is free. This is old school, not some hip fusion place with dancing girls.

xeepEFKfXdo50TNOt-43xw.review_text: Delicious! Bartender was friendly and the food was amazing!  Crab melts in your mouth. Definitely give it a try.

4fBGpyoWSY4SzQ7JZoX7vA.review_text: Great food, great service, great place.

EAVrB9nvw1WE0guMHH34EA.review_text: Definitely high end touristy typical for the Wharf in the city but the service is very professional and personable. Excellent actually. Partner had the tuna steak which was medium rare, but he told me it was delicious. I had the fried oysters with a Japanese paste for flavor and they were tasty. It was my first time having them this way. You get a lot for what you pay for which surprised me, but definitely worth every single bite.

0tddAiCypf-J3Rph5cTRDA.review_text: Scoma's has the freshest fish in the wharf. The swordfish is grilled to perfection.  My wife had the seared tuna and it was delicious. Although it can be pricey, the freshness of the fish is worth it.

IZ4zmvOP4zv3ajsBkD9w8Q.review_text: Cioppino.  Not very good.  Clams, prawns, crab, fish, scallop.  Crab was shredded. Fish was extra fishy.   Tomato soup based was very tomatoey. Nothing complex or subtle about the soup flavor.   I guess this is a landmark restaurant with a long history. They claim scenic views. You can see a few docked boats on the pier, but I didn't see any views of the bay.

e4iL_C8j1MwZE3wFxh-WZA.review_text: Just plain insanely good. Fresh, flavorful, superb. Our server Gus made the evening that much better. Their calamari appetizer was the best. I had the shellfish (lobster, shrimp, crab and scallops) with rice, pasta and vegetables. The amount of shellfish was outstanding. My husband had the scallop special. Worth every penny! Avoid the silly chain restaurants that serve boring same old, and come to this charming establishment that serves true seafood cuisine.

xJu_t3bD-rpdT59Y0KUILw.review_text: Touristy, yes. Institution, yes. Overpriced, yes. 2.5 star for food, 1 star for view, and .5 star for the atmosphere.  Nice to go once a year to just enjoy the ambience.  One of the better tourist joints on the wharves so if I have to frequent just one each time I'm in the City, I rotate among them.  Better food at better prices can be had elsewhere but when all is said and done, it's worth a visit if you've never been.

cnVxeco9iKF0et5YZvKrsg.review_text: I don't really know about everyone else - but I don't believe my experience is of the best as to be expected of this class of restaurant. The wait time was long, and the person running the front end is not truthfully forthcoming and accurate with wait times. The service was slow, expect to wait at least thirty minutes before you even get a glass of hydrogen hydroxide to consume after taking a seat.  We've basically ordered food for everyone at the group to try, the steak was meh - not the best steak when compared to Les Halles New York or even Bouchon Las Vegas. It was flavorless meat - hardly any substance or actual enjoyment to it.  I had lobster - and I'm really not that impressed. I believe it was overcooked - dry, and overpowering with seasonings. The crab stuff mushroom was not the best either.  The vegetables were bland, and the rice was dry and overcooked. I know what rice tastes like - as I tend to eat it everyday, and their rice is a place I would expect from something of a fast casual restaurant, not here.  Maybe it's because I'm a native of Seattle Seafood, or that I cook seafood myself - but I'm really not pleased with this restaurant and it's service and the quality of the food that was served given the prices listed.  I would suggest looking elsewhere if you're in the mood for a seafood dining.

pknnVqGB8rLvv512pTPyIg.review_text: Perfect restaurant for a nice seaside dinner! After some research, we couldn't have been happier with our discovery of this place. Though it looks like a dive from the outside, this place has class inside, not to mention the incredible location off the beaten path of Fisherman's wharf. We sat right next to the window and watched the sunset on the dock as we had our meal.  Make sure to make a reservation, try the California wine, and order the Caesar salad and garlic crab.

02tYMxGnwAwr_i2j5vh9XA.review_text: OMG. delicious. everything on the menu sounded so good I couldn't decide... I went with the famous cioppino... *see photo* YUMMMMMMYYYYYYY... free valet parking... loved it cant wait to go back...  the only thing I think they could do is fix it up a little clean deeply window areas ect... its tiny, and older and has a lot of history but doesn't mean you have to scrimp on the elbow grease...

d-WDfKTTwmThJKwOR5qDqw.review_text: Off the beaten path, so you do't have to worry about tourists. The seafood is very fresh and the staff is very attentive. Jean Marc took very good care of us. I highly recommend the clam chowder.

K5s226IQ6DQ4HNmy-9lang.review_text: It was an amaaaaazing experience yesterday ! We came back from our visit to Alcatraz so we went to the pier. My husband had the idea to have a food lunch at Scoma. Our waitress was VERY friendly. We had a cocktail (mmmm) and the main course gets 11/10 :) Fish is so fresh, you can still taste the sea ! The coffees were well made and left the resto with a big smile... Certainly a place to keep in mind.

rUP76_8OJclekKlui7OJ0A.review_text: Been a faithful at Scoma's for years but unfortunately, after I noticed a charge of 4% FOR EMPLOYEE HEALTH AND WELFARE, I will no longer be dining there.  Enough is enough and I don't feel like contributing another cent to this administration and how they  run things! Excellent food however.  Valet is great.  No less than a 45 minute wait.

45LqjHBFm5wgz9e2-vB1sQ.review_text: Delicious food and good service. Freshest fish I have ever eaten that I did not catch myself.

RzhLXQmzjuhxPPka6jw6rQ.review_text: Okay service, but not great....food was barely edible, too full of butter & sauce, used many techniques to hide the foods true taste...merely a place that has made it into a tour guide for inland based tourists.

931NrRnIU20iyMlTNUXfWw.review_text: I came with some friends for Dine About Town on a Sunday at 7:15 PM. We were seated at around 8:10, but we didn't start getting food until 9:05, which was a bit disappointing. I know it was busy, but it took nearly 25 minutes for the waiter to finally get down our order. Now onto the food:  Appetizer: Lobster Bisque - This bisque was delicious and packed a lot of flavor without being too much. I've had lots of bisques in the past that were very salty, but this was a good balance. It also had a bit of a spicy kick at the end of every bite.  Clam Chowder - This was not your typical clam chowder to say the least... I personally felt it lacked flavor. My friend described it as chicken noodle soup-esque and I have to agree. It was a bland chicken noodle soup with cream and clams instead of chicken.  Entrees: Seared Scallops over Linguine - I only had a taste of the scallops, so I can't comment on the pasta. The scallops were nicely cooked, had a good texture but it lacked the sweetness that I usually expect from them.  Lamb T-Bones - This was definitely the highlight of the evening for me. I asked for my lamb to be medium rare, and out come 3 good looking pieces of lamb. One of the pieces was a perfect medium, while the other 2 were perfect medium-rares - weird. it was seasoned well and the lamb was soft and amazing. the juices of the lamb seeped into the spinach and that was incredible as well.  Dessert: Tiramasu and Sourdough Breading Pudding - I love bread pudding, but I'm probably not going to order a sourdough one again. The raisins tasted sour after the caramel on top of the sourdough. That's just too much sour for me in a bread pudding. The tiramasu was great though. The coffee flavor had a little, but just enough sweetness to make this good for a fan of bittersweet things.  tl;dr - the wait was long, the portions are huge, would only come back for the bisque and lamb

ERjkjlCFjpN27V3nvn83xg.review_text: Had delicious food on a Sunday nite with great service. They accommodated very well to our 2yr old (stroller was folded and left by the hostess).  I would recommend reservations if going prime time b/c as we were leaving, it was very packed & people were waiting for a table. We were there right around 5:30 pm and they were opening their other dinner room, which got filled in 15 mins., if not less. All around, fantastic. Btw, I recommend the lobster bisque over the clam chowder. Amazing!!

TVRZY8f7ygulBocq8nYIFA.review_text: Scoma's is my families go-to restaurant when we are getting together up in the city. We have been coming here since I was a baby and it has never failed us. I also look forward to their fresh sourdough bread and butter and a cup of some of the freshest clam chowder I've ever had to start off the meal. I've gotten multiple fish dishes here but love the Scoma's pasta. My dad is a sucker for the cioppino and has ordered it for as long as I can remember. When my grandmother passed away we rented out a room at Scoma's and had a wonderful memorial dinner here for about 40 people.   All in all this is a great seafood restaurant on the water and we will be coming back time and time again for many years to come.

-WZH08M_-jsc5a40x2XLcw.review_text: This place is a gem on Fisherman's Wharf, assuming you're willing to pay a bit extra for the location and (IMO) quality of food and friendly service.  My family had a late dinner here which was absolutely delicious across the board. The server was friendly, old school, and didn't rush us at all.  - Oysters: Awesome - Mussells: Awesome - Pasta dishes with crab, lobster, scallops: Amazing, the amount of seafood/shellfish they toss into their pasta dishes is mindblowing.  Wine: Affordable list of bottles.   Even the bread's good.   Totally recommend, especially for out-of-towners who  don't mind a high-quality old school seafood restaurant right in the middle of Tourist Central.

2df2el0XrwUmSHdz9iEF7Q.review_text: We had the BEST waiter I have ever had.  I think his name was John B. The food was delicious and I loved eating with a view of the water.

p-w-1gh3aGEMPAL6-RwC4g.review_text: We tried the lazy man's cioppino and oysters, which were very good. The view is nice and atmosphere of the restaurant is pleasant.  It did get really busy around 6-7pm but there are quite a few tables, and second room with a view is especially nice.

vxG7J3h_MGX4Www60WyDVA.review_text: Overrated... pretty much sums it up for our experiences here. One of four plates was definitely worth it (the yellowfin), another would barely cut it for what I'd expect for this type of restaurant. The other two were just boring and lacking in flavor. The atmosphere was noisy and our server could have easily been a bit more courteous. For the price, don't take the gamble and go somewhere else.

V3alMhjWa3x0v8DlDp49Sw.review_text: Spectacular food. Salvatore. Chris. Tim. Are wonderful. Ask for them. The food is beyond good. The sauté sec. The lazy mans cioppinnio. The crab Louis. Are amazing. This is what San Francisco is all about. The potions are amazing and the service is friendly and helpful. . We have been coming for over 25 years and we feel at home, even if we come from New Orleans.

KXw5PSJqOHxKgLzmlAOZZg.review_text: ,,,,,Thanks to Yelps inept handling of their "Hornblower Cruise" we wound up at Scomas....less said about Yelp the better.  They sent out thousands of invitations to their Yelp favorites and "Vendors" who pay them for glowing reviews.  I got an invite and RSVP as asked.  We arrived on time and were denied boarding because we weren't on their preferred guest list.  No class operation.   .....anyhow being adults we decided to enjoy our own company and the beautiful day and walk up the Embarkadaro.  A tourist couple asked about the Waterfront Restaurant, I said I wouldn't go if they were buying, so recommended Scomas down on the Wharf.  As we walked along Pier 39 we ran into some old friends we hadn't seen in years who were also out enjoying the wonderful Summer like day... ....Told them about the Yelp screw up as we walked along...they hadn't been to Scomas in years...let's go.  The meal and adult conversation couldn't been better.   .....The Fetichini Alfredo with clams, lobster, shrimp and scallops...excellent  The Caesars salad and tall Tanqaray Tonic excellent...best of all the adult company... We all toasted Yelp and their strange way of doing business.....Fair warning...the tab we picked up was $200...

UxtmR9TXujlR7x-kESyxDw.review_text: Went here for my boyfriends birthday! He requested a seafood dinner. So researched all around and found Scoma's! Although I thought it could be a tourist trap, it actually wasn't.   My boyfriend ordered the Pasta Diplomatica and loved it. Plenty of different kinds of fish in a creamy sauce over linguine. He ate the whole thing which was a pretty large portion.   I ordered the Salmon and shrimp pasta with dill cream sauce. I will say mine wasn't as good as the Diplomatica. Next time I'm going to just order a fish meal.   We will be coming back and will make this our seafood dinner stop every time we visit San a Francisco. You must go here but don't get side tracked by all the tourist buzz.

QdQWkr7T-SCkklEQPCS9jA.review_text: Went here during VMworld in August of 2013. Sat at the bar for a bit while waiting for other friends to arrive. The bartender was super attentive and gave us a couple of samples of things he has made or over poured. Ordered some oysters and they were perfect. After a few drinks we went to the table and ordered. I had the BEST swordfish ever. It was swordfish piccata, and it was simply amazing. 10 out of 10. Had some wine with the meal, fresh bread and excellent service. The place is right on the water in the wharf and has a very cool feel to it. If you are in the area make a point to visit Scoma's.

c_AoxAZ-AjamrsYq5VQyrQ.review_text: Sand Dabs!  We love Sand Dabs. This N California treat is not always available or well prepared. Buy Scoma's is beautifully prepared. The staff is very attentive and seems to have been there a long time. The bread was so good we took ours with us. A lovely experience.

u8jjbJTtYPNjhTzQgloDTw.review_text: Sourdough bread was served cold not warm- gross - we Ordered a salad and calamari for an appetizer - salad was weak on flavor and dressing and calamari wasn't impressive at all- I would recommend switching from fritters to calamari strips - And dinner we had the lobster ravioli and blackened salmon. It Was decent good flavor. Small portions for such high prices. Our waiter was good though. Waste of  $100 in my mind.

Nh8yiMS4C6GmBEuFc-G2NQ.review_text: From the first greeting by John, our waiter, we suspected the meal would be special. All 6 of us agreed that this was an understatement.  The food was devine, service impecable, friendly, efficient. A perfect evening with friends! Thanks to all from the wait-staff to the chefs...job well done!

paNtPIcJtA_7TqwC8q27-g.review_text: Fav! I've been going to Scoma's since I was a baby. The bread is amazing and the food is great. The atmosphere is old school and great. The waiters, most of them, have worked there forever. Great views.

DGszSnRNWoAOtD8WGf9wpg.review_text: After my mother told me this was my father's favorite place to eat in SF period! I knew I had to come to this place and see what he loved so much. You see my dad passed away in the 80's and this place is still around.   Crab cocktail was our starter dish and it was right up there as the freshest crab I've eaten.  The dish we were told to order that my dad always loved was the Cioppino or as the bill says One Lazy Cioppino. It is a fisherman's stew of many fish, scallops, shrimps, crab, clams and mussels with a tomato base. It is thick and full of flavor. We split it between us and still have left overs for a few hours later while at Alcatraz.   Classy place with a blend of young folks and blue hairs alike. Go check it out if you are at the Wharf.

o0UY3pee1b09na7jTSCFwA.review_text: I had the Losbter with cheese. It was good, very fresh sea food, and there was A LOT of food.  Too much.   I give it 4 stars because:  - there was way too much cheese in the lobster - the presentation was sloppy as you can see in the photo,  - the bread was totally cold.  I even joked that it could be used as a cold pack.  The service was proper. Overall I had higher expectations for this place based on recommendations.  I  will go back and try a more simple sea food without all the cheese.

DUCVhBH9quiMZo5phvNzIw.review_text: Great food as well as service. The inability to make a reservation, outdated interior and located in a hyper touristy areas all detract me from wanting to come back again.

sMYNkPn5ecal3w2f48wO6A.review_text: Greatest place to visit in San Francisco. Hellava Martini and Shrimp Cocktail!

8C4PFBKUVNq0M3rNJSxoAQ.review_text: 2Stars $$$ Disappointing over price, must have new cheap owners $40 Chopino is now served with no crab, service was terrible you had to ask for missing items n more bread n butter. Crowed n they pack u in tight. Valet parking. Table with views are rare have to be persistent.

UOZNKvZ4pMtOsZr7QSQALA.review_text: I don't make it Scoma's often, but I try any time I'm near the wharf. They never fail to impress. From the white jacket service to top of the line fresh sea food it's definately a do not miss for me.   This trip included a beautiful Burrata served over balsamic covered heirloom tomatoes, and cup of their awesome clam chowder. If your looking for something heartier try the cioppino

Lccmw9Tyx5EKqWXKEOHvPQ.review_text: Chowder is just okay. Don't pay this much for a sub par meal.  Best choice is to stay away from the wharf.

Ag6w9WoQsHs7LoOUeIn92w.review_text: I decided to give this place a try based on all the amazing reviews and I'm glad I did. This place was amazing I got the catch of the day salmon blackened the seasoning was beyond amazing ! My brother got the salmon broiled which was also good if you don't like a lot of spices go with that one . We also got the ahi tuna which wasn't the best . The service on the other hand was a little frustrating not really that helpful. Overall I'm really happy we tried it

tZKF63NSI4tC_FYZVCS13w.review_text: I think it's funny when people rate this restaurant and downgrade it because of the ambiance. Guys--c'mon. Note the nautical decor. Now note the ol' friendly host. Also note where the god damn restaurant is. It's in a narrow alley behind a bunch of tourist shops for godsakes. It's not supposed to be super uppity. It might as well be a gathering place for old fishermen who enjoy the finer things in life, so if you're super trendy be wary!   However, diners should also note that it has nice white table cloths and equally shiny and white plates. It's somewhere in between fine and casual but definitely San Franciscan. But hey, I'm not stupid enough to go on a weekend night.  Now down to business. My first experience and best experience was with the cioppino. Good Lord, it had so much seafood, they really don't skimp. I've had a lot of cioppino and this one takes the cake. Fish in every bite. And incredibly fresh (except maybe for the baby Alaskan shrimp, but hey shrimp in every bite) The individual pieces of  petrale, mussels, clams, and prawns weren't overcooked at all. Which means the cooks know when to put the fish in.  It's not just tossed into the broth. Heavenly, broth I might add. And it's all served with a delicious and I mean delicious buttery piece of toast.  But the best thing is Scoma's doesn't pretend to be something it's not. It's behind the tourist shops. Down a smelly little alley. It's San Francisco and it's how they cook there seafood. And if you want your fish served in fusion cuisine contorted into a roll slathered with mayo in a more "hip" environment--well there's those kinds of places in the 7mile by 7 mile city too. Just not here.   So yes, the service might be a little slow. But your server more likely than has been there for 20+ years. Have mercy and just enjoy your fish.

cVVCy1JTIZsOGHWbB6LMuQ.review_text: A group of ladies celebrated here after finishing the Nike Women's marathon.  This place came highly recommended by one member as she previously lived in SF.  Love the fact you walk right past the boats that bring in the fresh catches each day on your way to the front door.  The lobster bisque was enjoyed by two girls and all entrees were equally delicious, especially the garlic mashed potatoes.  The servers must truly love their work as most have been around for 20+ years.  Friendly atmosphere where neighboring tables can engage in a chat over apps or dessert.  Minus one star solely due to the hostess.  We were seated in the bar area while we waited for our table, even with reservations.  Several other parties were called and about 20 mins later we asked where we were on the list.  She gave a look and said she had called us at least 3-4 times.  There were four of us carb depleted girls , with only one drinking, who couldn't wait to dive into a plate of anything.  Trust me, we were listening and weren't called.  The rest of the night made up for her snub.

PvqoIJmoM65QrVqE2K8eMQ.review_text: The food was good, BUT you ate wedged into a very tight area and you better like your neighbors. The service was nothing special. The bad review comes from the added 4% surcharge . When our bill came besides the tax there was a 4 percent surcharge and when we asked what it was for our server could not explain it. The charge is for there medical, the restraunt charges this to help cover the cost of the medical! I've felt this is out of line, they should tell us in advance! We will not be going back! Stay away from the Cioppino, my brother in law got a bad clam!

eGNDMI3F8d4VoAe9CYGSzw.review_text: I give it a 3 stars because Dine About Town was not the business. First, our lobster bisque and crab cake portion for starters were tiny! Paper thin pieces for crab cakes and less than a cup for the bisque.  Second, we ordered the pork with chimmichuri sauce and it was the dryest pork I had ever eaten. There was no gloss to it as there should be with meat when cooked to order. We also ordered the seared ahi, which was just okay. It was too done and not satisfying, but tasted better than the pork. Last, dessert.  We got the tiramisu and the sorbet. The tiramisu was in this tiny espresso cup!!! Literally a few bites of this. Dissapointed. Overall, my boyfriend and I were disappointed with this Dine About Town experience.

bK83JqfkLOOayKXjoaR62A.review_text: Incredible food and service was simply outstanding.  I recommend the clam chowder and I had the seafood mixed grill which was incredible.  I don't know if you can go wrong on this menu.  They also make service important and despite being in a group of over 20, the service was flawless and I didn't see any gaps in the delivery of appetizers, soup, and entrees.  Wine list was robust; however I recommend bringing your own wine and paying the rather modest $20 corkage fee.

BUT5nRU7jQ2WMU5Afrgheg.review_text: People I mention this place to were super down on it as it was too touristy.  I came on a cold (for NorCal) January weeknight.  It was all local regulars.  No families, kids, tourists, etc...  The staff are all old-timers, some who have a ton of energy and some who seem like they need to retire because they don't give a shit anymore and really aren't that interested in making your evening memorable.  The food was great for what I'd expect there - I had the lobster bisque, a seafood pasta, and the tiramisu was like 10 stars.  Seriously get the tiramisu.  I also had a few drinks and the bartenders seemed like pretty awesome people; low key, friendly, made great drinks.    I'd go back on a sunny day and see the water!  Great location.

r-udHOpqo67mPjaL_A99Rw.review_text: This was my first time here and I was very pleased. We made reservations and we only had to wait 20 minutes, well at least for today.  Very clean restaurant, narrow walking space but it's kinda big.   Large seafood menu and there's a giant wine selection.   The servers are really nice. When you order crab, they also put on bibs for you.  Come here for the clam chowder! It's amazing! Not too creamy or too watery. I was going to take a picture of it but I ended up just eating the whole thing. They chop up the clams, potatoes, and celery into small pieces so with every spoonful you get like a mouthful of everything. There was other ingredients in there too but I was way too hungry to observe. You can tell everything is fresh and didn't just plop it out of a can. I got the bowl for $10 which they do give a large portion. They have the cup for $9 but there's a total size difference. So I would recommend to just get the bowl, it's much more worth it since they give you much more.  We also got two orders of the dungeness crab, which tasted alright. It wasn't anything special, but it tasted fresh and that's always good in my book.  Every thing arrived pretty fast, we didn't wait too long which was good. But then again, I guess it depends on the day.  I would have to come back here in the future to try other seafood dishes.  But yes, come for the clam chowder and you'll be happy you did!

sMWHjqOe3nJxHRl7C8QX5A.review_text: For the price point, the food was good but not exceptional. The service was decent, but not great. I had the fresh grilled halibut with a butter sauce, which was mistakenly served without the sauce. The dish was bland and the halibut was a little dry. The restaurant is on a pier but views are mainly blocked by adjoining buildings. No one asked how the food was until well into the meal when I was able to ask for the sauce.  A solid 3-stars, but certainly no more.

HB0OEby4sXYE8hUqYY5Blw.review_text: Maybe should be a four star! I had many recommendations on this one. So I came with certain expectation, but was only disappointed.  The food here is good, not great! I gave 3 stars because it is too pricy! It sits along the water, view is very enjoyable!

NCHxHfSdx52uzrzja_skAA.review_text: Went here Sunday night for DAT. People aren't kidding about the long wait! We had to bum around for an hour or so before our seats were called, so definitely think about the waiting time if you want to dine here.  Once called, we were seated in a comfy booth and introduced to our waiter, Chris. Honestly, Chris is one of the reasons I'm a fan of this place- he has a friendly, grandfatherly air and will always keep you up-to-date on the status of your food & service. He even managed to help us substitute a DAT entree (this is HUGE) for one of my vegetarian friends.  But anyways, the food. Like most restaurants, Scoma gave us a basket of bread & breadsticks. I wasn't a huge fan of the bread, since I've never liked sourdough, but I guess that's more of an industrywide thing, so nothing you can do.  For the appetizer/"first" course, my friend Alan & I ordered the lobster bisque. As expected, it was very rich & creamy, though a tad salty, in my opinion. My friend's clam chowder, on the other hand, was delicious! Typically, I don't like clam chowder, but this was an exception! Although that might be because the clam chowder reminded me of a creamier version of chicken noodle soup. As Alan pointed out, the chowder wasn't very "clam-y", even though there WERE chunks of clam floating about the vegetables. Regardless, I loved it.  For the second course, I ordered scallops and linguini pomodora. The linguini was all right, not stellar, but the scallops more than made up for that. They were buttery and delicious, with a slight bit of crispiness. Ahh, so good! About halfway through the second entree, I felt completely stuffed and had to stop eating. Perhaps it was the clam chowder I consumed, or perhaps it was the generous portions we were given- either way, I literally had to get up and walk around the restaurant before I could go back and eat.  I also tried a bite of Alan's lamb chops, which were delicious & savory. Funny enough, the spinach was also completely infused with a smoky, lamb flavor, which really made the dish unique.  We finished up the meal with various desserts. I got the raspberry white chocolate cheesecake, which was less cheesy than the usual cheesecake I was accustomed too, but delicious nonetheless. I especially loved the bottom layer of the cheesecake, which was a chocolately crumble with a hint of mint. Mm!  My only complaint: there was a waitress (Irene), who had a completely DGAF mindset. While pouring water or grinding pepper, she spilled half of what she was doing, didn't seem to notice, and just went along her way. A bit annoying, especially when some sauces from dishes she was sweeping off the table dripped onto my Android. Sigh.  But the bottomline- this was a delicious restaurant that I would love to come back and try again! Especially the desserts. I'm still unsure whether or not the dinner was really worth $40, so the jury's still out on the success of this DAT meal.

f36Ec1f_qQ-ABkiR1KKscA.review_text: I loved the green salad the dressing was dilicious also the staff is great the view the fish and fried is very big dish i like it but better to order smaller portion the clam chowder is great and tasety

98ayax82c8mMTgxgkIw3Zw.review_text: I hadn't been to Scoma's in over 20 years so I was curious what it would be like today when a friend visiting from Los Angeles asked me to make a reservation. I was afraid the food and service might have declined as locals often refer to Scoma's as a place for grandparents and tourists. Not so! The food and service were excellent! We came at 5:30 pm, the time of our reservation and had our table of four until the place was nearly closed. Staff understood that I was having a "reunion" with a friend I had not seen since graduating girl's school 40 years ago. So they just let us and our families feel right at home without trying to push us out of our table to accommodate another set of diners.Surprising ,since the place was packed that night. One other notable aspect of service: the waitpersons are trained in proper wine service which includes wine pairing, presentation, opening and pouring...and by wine pairing I mean not only pairing to the food but also to what they perceive as your price point without asking. Our server got it all correct. I am a Court of Master Sommeliers (Level 2) Certified Sommelier and am Advanced Certified by WSET (Wine & Spirit Education Trust). I am so tired of going out to dine in San Francisco and watching servers who know nothing about wine or wine service try to upsell me on wine...and then botching service Thanks, Scoma's and Mathew (our server) for getting it right! My partner and I are locals and we will be back dining at your wonderful restaurant!

bMMRPKHC1LdASDbRHl7RnA.review_text: Came here for the Jan 2014 Dine About Town Dinner option but was very disappointed with the overall quality of the meal.   Starter - Dungeness crab cake - pretty good Main - Blackened shrimp with brown penne vodka tomato sauce. This was a pretty horrible dish; no flavor whatsoever. I asked the server for more sauce and they basically just brought a bowl of canned mashed tomatoes. Ragu sauce would have been a huge upgrade.  Dessert - lemon panna cotta - Okay, tasted more like cheesecake because it was so dense.   My boyfriend had: Starter - Lobster Bisque - Warm and satisfying Dinner - Seared Yellowtail Tuna Medium Rare - Bland Dessert - Chocolate brownie with caramel sauce and vanilla bean ice cream - Cold brownie saved by globs of caramel.   I definitely wouldn't go back to try out the regular menu.

KjnxhW5CSjjKVzytq_OM6A.review_text: Let me start by saying that I have been coming to Scoma's for years. Unfortunately after my visit tonight, I don't think I'll be back. San Francisco is full of too many great places for me to keep visiting simply for the nostalgia of what this place used to be.   First, I'd agree with other reviewers that this isn't a modern fine-dining establishment. The décor is definitely a throwback to old-school seafood restaurants, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing in my opinion. Lots of wood paneling and memorabilia on the walls. Tourists used to look in, see the prices and fancy clothes and turn around to head back to Bubba Gump Shrimp Co., but those days are long gone. There were plenty of people in camouflage cargo shorts waltzing in. That might be more a statement about society than the restaurant, but there it is. Sorry if you like camouflage pants or Bubba Gump.   The service has always been a high point at Scoma's. Tonight was no exception. The wait staff was very attentive and helpful. The only minor blemish for gluten-free diners: tonight was our first visit after my wife had to adopt a gluten-free diet regimen. We looked ahead to ensure there were good options on the menu (there were) but our waiter wasn't very knowledgeable about the different options. Some of the menu items that would normally be gluten-free (even simple grilled fish) didn't carry that designation, which was confusing. Just something to consider for those with a dietary restriction.   The food was ultimately the reason for the low score in my book. We started with the highly vaunted lobster bisque. It barely even tasted like lobster, much less contained any - it was more tomato bisque than anything. I've had better store-bought.   With entrées, I went with cioppino while my wife chose crab risotto. The seafood part of my cioppino was pretty good - a little squid-heavy for my taste and with decidedly non-traditional lump crab (is that why it's "lazy" cioppino?), but overall it's good and there's plenty of it. The problem was the tomato sauce. It tasted like a cross of canned spaghetti sauce and tomato soup poured over the seafood - bland and weirdly thick, not the spicy, wine and tomato-y broth that usually comes with the dish. Just plain weird.   The risotto was even worse. First, they used long-grain rice, not Arborio or another short-grain rice. I'm no food snob but it looked like they dumped Minute rice onto the plate. It didn't look edible, much less appetizing. Second, there were random peas, mushrooms and tomatoes throughout (none of which was mentioned on the menu). Risotto should be rich, creamy and flavorful. This was none of those.

OpFr1MdG2MjChr1ucdp1nQ.review_text: Our meal was well worth the 45 minute wait. Making reservations is definitely recommended. I had the Mixed Fresh Seafood Grill with swordfish, salmon and shrimp. It was served with grilled vegetables; peppers, zucchini and egg plant. The spices were well flavored but not overpowering.   The service was good, but not intrusive; and the atmosphere was casual yet elegant at the same time. I strongly recommend Scomas to anyone in the San Francisco area.

h4oOQdnfjpEHbygEJDsFbg.review_text: The last thing this place needs is another 5-star review, but I feel obligated to give them something after they gave us such a wonderful meal. We arrived on a Saturday evening with two other couples and no reservation; so we had to wait to be seated. The place was packed and I was not very hopeful of getting seated very quickly (even though the hostess did say 20minutes); so we made our way to the bar. We got some drinks; chatted it up; and before I was half-way done with my beer we were called to a table and seated.   We started the meal off with the crab cakes and fried calamari appetizers and they were good, but not great. I ordered the "Lazy Man's" Cioppino (LMC) and my wife got the Smoked Salmon Linguini. The LMC had a hefty price tag of $40 but it was worth every penny. The bowl came loaded with shrimp, fish, clams and scallops! It must've been a 80-20 ratio of seafood to sauce and I was afraid it was going to be the other way around. I did partake of my wife's Smoked Salmon Linguini and it, too, was terrific. The other two gentleman in our party got steaks- which I thought was going to be a mistake since I'd personally never order beef at a seafood joint, but if you want a steak you want a steak. They both said they were great and would order it again given the chance.   Our server, John, was great at making recommendations; answered all our questions and was very attentive (but not too attentive; you know what I'm saying).   The price tag was a little hefty, but well worth it. I can't wait to visit Pier 39 again so I can dine here again.
